column10: b'b\' Well this seems to be more of a problem with the server if I\\\'m reading RFC 2616 correctly: url   The Content-Length entity-header field indicates the size of the entity-body
column11: in decimal number of OCTETs
column12: sent to the recipient or
column13: in the case of the HEAD method
column14: the size of the entity-body that would have been sent had the request been a GET.  An example is  Applications SHOULD use this field to indicate the transfer-length of the message-body
column15: unless this is prohibited by the rules in section 4.4. (And section 4.4 doesn\\\'t mention anything about sending data on a GET request.)  Any Content-Length greater than or equal to zero is a valid value. Section 4.4 describes how to determine the length of a message-body if a Content-Length is not given.  Note that the meaning of this field is significantly different from the corresponding definition in MIME
column16: where it is an optional field used within the "-body" content-type. In HTTP
column17: it SHOULD be sent whenever the message\\\'s length can be determined prior to being transferred
column18: unless this is prohibited by the rules in section 4.4.\''

column10: b'b" Requests opens many files. Some of those files are opened for certificates
column11: but they are opened by OpenSSL and not by Requests
column12: so those aren\'t maintained. Additionally
column13: Requests will also open
column14: if needed
column15: the file
column16: the hosts file
column17: and many others.  You will be best served by using a tool like to work out which files are opened. There is a strict list of system calls that lead to file descriptors being allocated
column18: so you should reasonably swiftly be able to enumerate them. That will also let you know whether there is a problem or not. But
column19: yes
column20: I\'d expect that if you\'re *actively making* 1000 connections over HTTPS then at peak load we could easily use over 1000 FDs."'

column10: b'b" Albert\'s question on Stackoverflow [HTTP: POST request receives a 302
column11: should the redirect-request be a GET?]url  was [answered]url  by Julian Reschke who points to [ticket 160]url  of httbis working group. In [comment 29]url  of this ticket there\'s a link to [changeset 1428]url  which **allows POST->GET rewriting for 301/302**. In light of this I think Requests should follow current UAs\' behavior in regard to rewriting POST to GET for 301 and 302 status codes. This
column12: according to section 7.3 of the [latest]url  (1428) draft of _
column13: part 2: Message Semantics_
column14: also means that redirect can be carried out **without** user intervention because GET method is idempotent."'

column10: b'b" Let\'s see what does."'
b'b" ### Proposal1. Non-safe methods still have default to  .2. A new config setting called will be set to by default.3. If is
column11: a 301\'d will follow the browser behavior.4. If is
column12: a 301\'d will follow the RFC behavior."'

column10: b"b' What about defaulting to for non-safe methods?'"
b"b' I think that should default to . In general I prefer software to do things the correct way
column11: even if that correct way breaks when other people do things incorrectly. However I also prefer it when software that does do things the correct way gives me the flexibility to relax the restrictions in order to handle the case of someone else doing it wrong. In general I think that doing something that violates the  etc should require being explicitly allowed which will not only make the consumers of poorly written web sites reflect upon
column12: and maybe find a better way of doing something within the specs
column13: but can also be a trigger to the websites to fix their site to work within the RFC. Which the web as a whole is a much better place when places follow the standards.'"

column10: b'b" Ok
column11: so this is something that\'s been bothering me as well (i\'ve got use-cases involving posting large files
column12: potentially multi-GB). So i took a crack at it. My changes are based on the observation that
column13: except for a couple of lines of code in  which read any files passed into ram
column14: and the encode_multipart_formdata() function itself
column15: everything else is happy with the files remaining as file objects. Particularly
column16: the httplib backend is happy for body to be a file. The complication of course is that we can\'t directly send the file as the entire body
column17: but rather it must be framed by -data boundaries and headers. My solution was creating a file-like class that stores its contents as fragments of the whole body. These fragments may be either strings (framing text
column18: string fields) or file objects. When httplib ultimately tries to send it
column19: it walks through its set of fragments
column20: coalescing them into blocks of the size requested. No more than 8 KB of each file will be read at a time (the block size passed by httplib to read()). Technically the change is to the urllib3 package
column21: with a small change to  to take advantage of it. The commit is 025427818703fb6c79ed14853789c1e7411aff36
column22: although I can\'t say i\'m particularly happy with it (hence no pull request). I\'m feeling that i\'m missing something and probably breaking code (although it passes the tests). Anyone got any ideas? Is this the sort of thing that should be fixed at an architectural level instead?"'

It just happens to be reusing that function by importing it from urllib3. There\\\'s no reason they have to share the same copy of the function other than sanity. :) Anyway

column11: the approach you took is essentially the same as mine but using a separate multipart encoding generator and a file-like object to wrap around it
column12: whereas i combined the two into a single object (sort of). Your approach is much nicer i think. One benefit of my approach though is that once you\'re in the middle of a large file
column13: the call to read() from httplib is passed fairly directly to the underlying file
column14: whereas in that implementation the reading from the underlying file and the read from httplib may be using mismatched blocks. which means a bunch of extra string concatenation and data always being left in leftover. It might be worth returning less data than requested by httplib once to sync up or something. Although my implementation has far too much string copying as well. The blocksizes involved in both seem a little wastefully small as well. Anyway

column10: b'b" That\'s not a valid URL this should be an error. The user _must_ encode their URL components before combining them
column11: you can\'t possibly guess after the fact which characters were intended to be used literally and which weren\'t. If you must support requesting a unicode URL
column12: you should at least restrict the encoding to only affect non-ascii characters (since they couldn\'t have possibly be meant literally
column13: and therefore encoding them is at least reasonable
column14: if not strictly correct)."'

column10: b'b" @gfxmonk it\'s not a URL
column11: it\'s an IRI. Quoting needs to be optimized and optional."'

column10: b'b" @kennethreitz What do you mean by optimised? Quicker? Or restricted to non-ASCII characters? I admit I hadn\'t heard of IRIs before now
column11: but from a quick skim of the spec converting IRIs sounds like it must not escape an existing percent character
column12: which the current code is doing."'

column10: b'b" That\'s exactly what I mean :) I\'m going to look closely at what chrome does. It seems to do this as we all expect."'

column10: b'b\' Hi. I\\\'m the author of the post @gfxmonk posted above. I\\\'ve had a look at the requests library and fixed both of the bugs in this thread. My branch [py3-uri-encoding]url  contains both fixes
column11: as well as test cases. There are two separate issues: the double-encoding and the quoting of reserved characters. (Perhaps we should have two bugs and two branches
column12: but I was short on time.) First
column13: the double-encoding is only a problem on Python 3 for me. In Python 2
column14: it works great -it unquotes and then quotes the path
column15: which means that any illegal characters (such as \\\'<\\\') become quoted (to "%3C")
column16: while any already-quoted characters (such as "%3E") remain quoted. It works on Unicode characters too. However
column17: in Python 3
column18: it has completely different behaviour: it simply encodes the path to UTF-8 (not necessary
column19: since Python 3\\\'s quote automatically does this if given a Unicode string) and then quotes it. This results in double-quoting: \\\'<\\\' becomes "%3C"
column20: but "%3E" becomes "%253E". My fix was basically to remove the Python 3 specific code and make it work the same as Python 2. I had to make a quick fix to
column21: and then it worked. On Python 3
column22: it now just does the unquote and the requote
column23: and that works. As for the quoting of reserved characters
column24: that is a more tricky issue. It is essentially the same problem as I outlined in my [blog post]url  For some reason
column25: all of this only concerns the path (I\\\'d have applied it to the full URI
column27: I\\\'m just addressing how the path is handled). The current behaviour is to quote every character in the path except for \\\'/\\\'
column28: \\\'%\\\' and most of the unreserved characters. That violates [RFC 3986]url You should NOT be tampering with any reserved characters. But I understand the desire to a) encode illegal characters (such as spaces and non-ASCII characters) so they form a valid URI
column29: and b) unencode unreserved characters (such as \\\'-\\\') so they are easier to read without changing the semantics of the URI. This took a bit of work
column30: but I have rewritten requote_path so that it behaves the following way:1. Unquote only the unreserved characters
column31: leaving reserved and illegal characters as-is.2. Quote only illegal characters
column32: leaving reserved and unreserved characters as-is. Note that I have also changed how the tilde (\\\'~\\\') character is treated -for some reason Python treats it as a reserved character
column33: which is wrong. It is unreserved
column34: so it ought to be unquoted. That means that percent-encoded unreserved characters will end up being unquoted (which is legal
column35: because they are equivalent either way)
column36: illegal characters will end up being quoted (which is required for a valid URI)
column37: and reserved characters will remain exactly as they were. This solves the original problem of this bug report (I can successfully pull down that eBay URL) because the special characters in the path \\\'=\\\' and \\\'$\\\' are left unquoted. There isn\\\'t any point in making this "optional" -the current behaviour is a violation of the RFC and is erroneously tampering with valid URIs. If you must make it optional
column38: you should make the correct behaviour the default
column39: and add an option to quote all reserved characters in the path. I have included comprehensive test cases for all of the behaviour described above. P.S. As you mentioned you were interested
column40: in my [blog post]url  I described exactly how Chrome performs URI cleaning. It is largely the same as I have implemented here
column41: but it has a few wonky characters that don\\\'t get escaped properly.\''

column11: however even though the HTTP status code is included in the error messagestring
column12: this does not necessarily provide a clean API with which to interfaceover the request\'s status_code when an error occurs. Particularly this is useful when using a module or class that wraps requestsand returns some parsed response but leaves error handling up to whateveris using it. For instance
column13: if such a class were to call raise_for_status
column14: while it\'s possible to see if a string representation of an HTTP code is in theerror message via str(404) in (str)

b'b" I\'ve just started looking into this
column11: and I can explain the behaviour of the second case. The list of tuples you provided to has called on it. Dictionaries (obviously) don\'t allow duplicate keys
column12: but your list of tuples has duplicate keys
column13: so the last item in the iterable takes the value for that key. Exactly the same behaviour is shown if you provide a list of tuples to without the argument
column14: so I\'d assume that this is intended behaviour. I\'m significantly less sure about your first case. The actual exception is occurring in urllib3
column15: which does not expect to be passed a list. If I had to hazard a guess
column16: I\'d say that the fix should be applied to requests
column17: not urllib3
column18: because requests already has edge case code for lists in [ ]url  It\'s a fix I\'m prepared to write
column19: but I would want @kennethreitz to confirm that this is a bug
column20: and not actually correct behaviour
column21: first."'

column10: b'b" I actually prefer the former because the people who need it are the ones who know they\'ll need it and they\'re few enough that it won\'t cause too many complaints. However
column11: if we\'re going to be consistent with the existing API
column12: the latter would be the way to implement it. Currently
column13: urllib3 (and requests) will provide the API to send HTTPS requests without the ssl module present but will fail in the case where the ssl module is not available. In other words
column14: the API is there and you can use it but it just won\'t work and that is indicated by an exception. As to re-opening this
column15: that\'s up to @kennethreitz. The issue of course (with all of this) is that we\'re currently under a feature freeze (#1165
column16: #1168) so I\'m not sure if the work is even worth doing because it might not be accepted."'

column10: b'b\' Let me be a bit clearer: what I meant by the second alternative was "Try to use SNI if the optional deps are available
column11: but still use SSL as we always have it they aren\\\'t.". This shouldn\\\'t break anything existing up to now. As for reopening (or not) the issue
column12: IMHO
column13: this issue shouldn\\\'t be taken lightly. requests can become useless without SNI support for many scenarios. In particular
column14: multiple domains on a single IPv4 host without SNI become impossible. And additional IPv4 addresses are out of the questions for many users (due to their cost). In any case
column15: this is half feature
column16: half bug
column17: though I\\\'ll await @kennethreitz\\\'s reply regarding reopening the issue. \''

column10: b'b" Note that JSON is always supposed to be encoded in one of the UTF encodings; UTF-8 is the default
column11: but -16 and -32 are allowed too. The improvement thus is to _not_ use (which uses chardet to guess wrong in the case where no encoding has been set) but to detect the UTF encoding used instead; the first 4 bytes are enough to determine this. The [section 3 of the JSON RFC]url  tells you how to do this even. I\'d say: when no encoding has been set
column12: use and use the RFC rules to detect the encoding used and pass that to the function. If that raises an error
column13: or _has_ been set
column14: fall back to  . (Correction:  only handles UTF-8 or Unicode objects)."'

column10: b"b' [Useful test case]url  it does not specify an encoding
column11: the contained JSON is correctly encoded as UTF-8
column12: but chardet pegs it as and the end-result is that you get mis-decoded content in  . Using gives correct results. Work-around: set to before accessing  .'"

column10: b'b" Some updates:1) Calling () explicitly before calling lsof fixes the issue (as expected)2) The following shows a snippet of strace running the test Python script in the gist url  Look closely at the gist script and at the 2 write(1
column11: ...) lines at the bottom. The close() syscall should have appeared there!Looking further down the strace: The first socket doesn\'t get closed
column12: the second one does. Whats wrong with socket\'s close() method? 3) The combination of the 2 discoveries above made me think that maybe _()_ isn\'t calling _()_
column13: but as further investigation revealed
column14: the actual socket is implemented in C and is closed from there by means of reference counting. The socket is closed when the object is finalized. I then used objgraph to print the backrefs to the actual _sock object (the C object inside the Pythonic wrapper in __ from stdlib) and noticed the difference between the socket that gets properly closed and the one that is left open: The broken one has an __ instance which references it through its _fp_ member. Digging deeper
column15: I eventually found out that __ (_r_ is the request returned from _()_ in the test script) references the 302 redirection request. If I clear __
column16: the garbage socket gets disposed...I think now would be a good time for people familiar with requests code to jump in... **TL;DR**:  keeps a reference to the redirection response
column17: which in turn keeps a reference to the
column18: which in turn keeps a reference to the socket and this is why we\'re seeing the \'junk\' socket. Perhaps someone familiar enough with  internals could hint at this?"'

column10: b'b" This is extremely helpful

column12: but can help with that: [url  But I\'m not clear on the mechanics of why this happens. In general we are hoping not to rely on the semantics of the garbage collector for socket disposal
column13: since we are also targeting pypy
column14: which doesn\'t use reference counting and thus has less  garbage collection behavior. So ideally the fix would be something other than trying to zero out the refcount of the socket object. However
column15: as per this comment in  : there may be no other way. This patch should drop the reference to the socket from the history list; could you see if it fixes the problem for you? [url  I\'d like to think more about this

column10: b'b" url  8.1.2.2 Pipelining(...)A client wishing to send a non-idempotent request SHOULD wait to send that request until it has received the response status for the previous request. According to this client may choose not to wait for body yet alone read it. Side note: Although the above statement is in the Pipelining section it seems to describe more general situation of sending requests using the same connection (which doesn\'t have to be pipelining). It could be inferred from another statement from the same section _Clients SHOULD NOT pipeline requests using non-idempotent methods (...)_"'
b'b" Oh
column11: thanks
column12: that\'s very relevant. I think this is not a behavior we can realistically support in Requests
column13: even for idempotent requests. It sounds like under the pipelining semantics
column14: sending a new request before the old response has been read SHOULD cause the server to queue up the new response behind the old response. Thus

column10: b"b' umbrella ticket to resolve iteration / read size / chunked encoding questions'"
b'b\' This ticket is intended to aggregate previous discussion from #539
column12: and #597 about the default value of used by and  . cc @mponton @gwrtheyrn @shazow Issues:1. The default read size of is 1 byte; this is probably inefficient2. Requests does not expose the ability to read chunked encoding streams in the "correct" way
column13: i.e.
column14: using the provided octet counts to tell how much to read.3. However
column15: this would not be suitable as the default implementation of anyway; not all websites are standards-compliant and when this was tried it caused more problems than it solved.4. The current default read size for is 10kB. This is high enough that iteration over lines can be perceived as unresponsive no lines are returned until all 10kB have been read.5. There is no "correct" way to implement using blocking I/O
column16: we just have to bite the bullet and take a guess as to how much data we should read.6. There\\\'s apparently some nondeterminism in
column17: I think because of the edge case where a read ends between a and a  .7. is backed by
column18: which operates on raw byte strings and splits at byte boundaries. I think there may be edge cases where we could split the body in the middle of a multi-byte encoding of a Unicode character. My guess at a solution:1. Set the default to 1024 bytes
column19: for both and  .2. Provide a separate interface (possibly  ) for iterating over chunks of pages that are known to correctly implement chunked encoding
column20: e.g.
column21: Twitter\\\'s firehose APIs3. We may need our own implementation of that is deterministic with respect to our chunking boundaries
column22: i.e.
column23: remembers if the last-read character was and suppresses a subsequent  . We may also need to build in Unicode awareness at this level
column25: decode as much of the body as is valid
column26: then save any leftover invalid bytes to be prepended to the next chunk. Comments and thoughts are much appreciated. Thanks for your time!\''

column10: b"b' @slingamn thanks so much for stepping up with this ;)'"
b'b\' I\\\'m not sure using 1024 as the default size for is appropriate
column11: I think it should be 1 byte. Don\\\'t get me wrong
column12: **I KNOW** how bad this is for performance. But I stick with my original reasoning: If someone iterates on
column13: lines should be processed as soon as they are available and there should be no chance of "hanging" with complete lines in the buffer. The interface is called so it should do just that by default. A knowledgeable developer that wants better performance could still decide to use a larger read size knowing that it could mean that the read process will hang until the specified amount is read or the stream closed and that some lines could come in late. I love because it is fun and easy to use first
column14: yet very powerful. This is why I think should behave as expected even if it means poor performance. This decision should simply be documented. Newcomers will appreciate this (i.e. works as expected out of the box) while more experienced devs can still fiddle with the buffer size. That said
column15: should definitely have a larger default read size. The previous one was 10K if I remember correctly. The newly proposed one is 1K. I\\\'m not sure which one make a better default. +1 for  .\''

column10: b'b" I think I\'m missing something but why must hang when it has complete lines in the buffer? Why can\'t we scan for completed lines (  or such) and yield it just the same even if we\'ve read less than the default size?"'
b"b' @shazow Because the synchronous network read call will not return until the specified amount of bytes has been read or the stream is closed. Thus
column11: is you use a 1K read size and the server returns lines averaging 100 bytes
column12: you will have to wait for the server to return at least 11 lines before return any lines and your Python code is executed. If one line is sent every minute
column13: it will take 11 minutes before your code is even aware of the first line sent by the server.'"

column10: b"b' Ah I see what you mean. For some reason I was thinking in local IO terms. Thanks for the clarification! I wonder if there is any way to do it timeout-based
column11: such that it will read as much as it can in N ms and process
column12: loop.'"

b'b" I would like to jump in because it appears that a bit of the above discussion is based upon a false premise: that a synchronous network receive of _n_ bytes will block until at least _n_ bytes are received (or
column11: presumably
column12: the socket has closed). This is not
column13: in fact
column14: the case
column15: and Unix network programming would be a shambles if it were \\xe2\\x80\\x94 think of the disaster that every network program would face: applications would have to make the horrible decision to either read data byte-by-byte
column16: or block indefinitely if they overestimated
column17: even very slightly
column18: the amount of data about to arrive on a socket. Network programmers would all stand impaled upon the horns of a dilemma. Everyone might use Windows for network programming instead. :) But
column19: fortunately
column20: the plain normal vanilla blocking synchronous version of the call is merciful to us: it only blocks waiting as long as _no data at all_ is ready to be consumed! As soon as _even a single byte_ of data arrives in an incoming packet
column21: your beefy call to will return _that single byte_ and your program is off and running again. There is _no penalty_ for giving permission to return lots of data if a lot of data arrives in a single packet
column22: or arrives in several packets while the operating system is still getting around to scheduling your thread again. It is true that
column23: for those rare exceptional cases where you really _want_ to stay blocked because you really know that you need _n_ bytes before you can do anything useful
column24: there exists a POSIX flag that you can pass to so that your program really does block until lots of data arrives. But that is a very rare flag to specify
column25: for all of these reasons that we have put on the table here. So what is the problem here
column27: @mponton actually lets the cat out of the bag without knowing it! Look carefully at this phrase from his reply to @shazow: \\xe2\\x80\\x9c\\xe2\\x80\\xa6the synchronous network read call\\xe2\\x80\\xa6\\xe2\\x80\\x9d \\xe2\\x80\\x9cRead\\xe2\\x80\\x9d call? What? Who would do a call on a socket? While POSIX does allow and on sockets for those extremely rare cases where you pass a socket to a library that is only designed for talking to files
column28: it\'s not something you would ever do in a network program\\xe2\\x80\\x94you would lock yourself up waiting for _n_ bytes to arrive even if less than _n_ bytes were available immediately! Who would do _that?_ Why
column31: that\'s right. Instead of simply sitting in a tidy standard loop and slowly filling a buffer until an end-of-line is visible
column32: the author of **wraps the socket in a fake file-like object with and completely abandons all of the benefits of network programming under Unix!** They gain a tiny bit of convenience\\xc2\\xa0\\xe2\\x80\\x94 and maybe
column33: way back when it was written
column34: C-level performance? \\xe2\\x80\\x94 by having a Python file-like object watch for the end-of-line character for them. But they **completely disabled the ability to stream live data from the network** by making this choice
column35: probably because they were operating in an era when people read and wrote network payloads whole anyway. I recommend that Requests move off of  . It does very
column36: very little for you; it could be re-implemented much more simply with and in a day or two
column37: given the simplicity of HTTP. There is no reason why Python or Requests shouldn\'t have line-based or content-based iteration that returns the moment that enough data has arrived to satisfy the caller; you just need to move off of a broken implementation that wantonly imposes the semantics of the call on what is really a socket capable of doing if you\'ll just ask nicely!"'

column10: b'b" I need to go have dinner
column11: but another quick note that I\'ll expand on later: there\'s also no reason that should find UTF-8 a challenge
column12: because the pair of bytes look exactly the same in UTF-8 \\xe2\\x80\\x94 and since _every byte_ of a multi-byte character in UTF-8 has the high bit set
column13: no multi-byte character or sequence of them could accidentally have sitting inside. So you just need to call getting raw bytes until you see the sequence
column14: and _then_ pass the sequence of bytes \\xe2\\x80\\x94 that you know already is a single line \\xe2\\x80\\x94 to the decoder to be turned into a string."'

column10: b"b' @slingamn There is a danger here: once the socket has been wrapped with a file-like object by
column11: there is a chance that the stdio buffering will have read a bit _past_ the end of the first line and
column12: after returning that line to you
column13: will hold in its buffer a good bit of data that lay _after_ the line ending. Usually this is no problem
column14: as when you next issue or the file buffering simply draws data from its buffer first before then turning to the file descriptor for more. But if you try to go _around_ the stdio input buffering and read directly from the socket
column15: you will be missing the chunk of data (if any) that had been read past the end of the line! Unfortunately
column16: stdio provides no way to introspect a object and rescue the contents of its buffer without also probably inducing the punishment of a blocking  . So once you have even for a moment used a file-like object to do your reading for you
column17: you are committed: you cannot return to raw socket I/O. It might be possible to craft your own file-like object; I found
column18: for example
column19: that in let me provide my own object that implements and on top of a socket
column20: and the problem was solved. It is also possible that you might want a way around the problem
column21: or even a guarantee that no data will be trapped there. I am often wrong about such things
column22: and you may see a way out where I have not yet. But I think the whole issue is what lead the Python 3 people to ditch I/O entirely and write a new dedicated Python buffering subsystem directly atop POSIX system calls. If only we were working under Python 3
column23: we might not even face these issues. Alas that all of our favorite toys keep us toiling under Python 2!'"

column10: b'b\' @brandon-rhodes is implemented entirely in Python (in 2.7 at least) and is a wrapper around the low-level socket object. It is not a FILE \\\\* object so it has nothing to do with stdio. Its internal buffering is implemented using StringIO. It has a method that does exactly what we need (i.e. use to get data from the network into a buffer and return immediately when an EOL is encountered) for (minus unicode decoding). @slingamn The file-like object in is a   wrapping a  . The later uses to wrap the socket object but does no expose that socket object and thus it is not possible to call from a object (well

column19: rather than just the part after localhost:8000 not sure why that is. We have a HTTP proxy setup in this environment (Microsoft ISA
column20: I believe)
column21: which uses authentication (I\'ve put the  in the variable itself). I\'ve set the environment variable and put localhost and 127.0.0.1 in there. However
column22: requests seems to still be doing something funky with the proxy. If I actually unset requests works fine: So firstly
column23: I\'m curious why requests doesn\'t work with the proxy variable set? And secondly
column24: is there any any way to get it to respect  ? Cheers

column10: b'b" I have a similar problem where I just want to disable the proxy for certain requests (connecting to internal WebServices that are not available outside our DMZ). After digging through the requests code to find out how proxies are handled and how proxy configuration is loaded I have come up with a work-around to disable the proxy when needed: How this works
column11: if the _proxies_ parameter is passed to the get (or other http method) it is has any empty entries removed before checking if there are any values still in the dictionary. If the dictionary is empty then the variables are loaded from the environment using the method __. By including a value in the \'no\' key then the proxies parameter is used which includes empty _http_ and _https_ entries thereby disabling the proxy. The method is a bit hacky but does solve the issue."'

column10: b'b" By default
column11: trusts any environment variables the system has in place
column12: and assumes you want to use them (which is usually the default behaviour of UNIXy programs). You can disable this behaviour either by using @timsavage\'s method (which is clever
column13: nice workaround)
column14: or by setting the config value to
column15: like so: You can see everything you can change with the config dictionary [here]url  Hope that helps!"'

column11: Hmm
column12: yes
column13: but by the same logic
column14: wouldn\'t also trust the environment variable as well? This is meant to be a list of specific hosts for which we don\'t use the proxy and it\'s supported by most *nix HTTP clients
column15: as far as I\'m awarewget url lynx url chef url  just to pick a few random ones. I don\'t think it\'s a case of not trusting the http_proxy variable
column16: but more just having support for the no_proxy variable as well? Cheers

column10: b'b" I seem to remember this having come up before
column11: though I can\'t find a good example of this issue. @idan
column12: you\'re way more familiar with OAuth than me. Is the principle supposed to be that OAuth doesn\'t include the body for signing purposes
column13: or is it just specifically not supposed to sign the body for  ?"'

column10: b"b' Per the [spec (3.4.1.3.1)]url  OAuth1 only signs parameters from the request body if it is single-part
column11: encoded according to
column12: and has the according header set. If any of these three requirements are not met
column13: the request body is ignored for the purposes of generating a signature
column14: as per the spec.'"

column10: b'b" If this isn\'t clear
column11: it means that file uploads are never signed according to the OAuth1 spec."'

column10: b"b' Awesome. So
column11: my understanding of this situation is that JSON data
column12: while encoded correctly
column13: does not have the correct Content-Type header
column14: so we should not be including it in the signing. Correct?'"

column10: b"b' The _only_ kind of data from the POST body which should be included in the signature base string (and thus signed) is form-urlencoded data
column11: and even then only if the correct Content-Type header is set. JSON data is obviously not form-urlencoded
column12: and specifying the Content-Type will not magically make it so. :) So yes
column13: JSON data should be (correctly) ignored for the purposes of signing. Put another way
column14: if you include two requests that are otherwise identical but one of which contains JSON body data
column15: the signature should not vary.'"

column12: but the requests wrapper does not. Here is an example. Hopefully there is a workaround for this :) Socks works with almost every other module

column10: b"b' Very interesting.  I wonder if this is a bug with socks or not.'"

column10: b'b" The quickest explanation is Amazon. The next quickest explanation is that when doing requests in some cases (like when interacting with Amazon) the server absolutely requires order be preserved. You could do that (ostensibly) by passing an but the old implementation would convert it to a dict and magically all hell would break loose. I see no way in which removing that built-in niceness is acceptable to anyone whether on the session level or on the request level.That\'s exactly what I had in mind with the one reservation about ordering. Returned and prepared should both use straight  s. Those don\'t care about order in either case. This is why I\'m starting to think we should ship that first

column14: and are deliberately exposed parts of the API

column17: especially if is the default (which it probably should be)

column21: and needs to be clearly documented and accompanied by a decent version number bump."'

column10: b'b" Hey requests folks
column11: new to the project and found my way here pretty quickly after browsing the docs and noticing requests uses a dict-like structure for headers and so can apparently silently drop headers when there are multiple with the same key. Is that documented anywhere? I looked and was surprised to not see that documented in any of these places but maybe I missed it: url url url url  I say surprised just given Werkzeug\'s example as well as the prevalence of multiple headers in the wild (e.g. etc.)
column12: but maybe I\'m just misunderstanding the impact? Just tried and looks like requests is combining the two set-cookie headers into a single one
column13: so not a perfectly faithful representation of the response but I guess better than dropping the second header completely. Anyway
column14: just thought I\'d ask if this would be a good time to take a look at fixing this again
column15: or at least documenting it? Would it help to split this out into one ticket for headers and another for query params in case fixing one is easier than both at the same time? Thanks for any  and for the great work on requests in general."'

column10: b'b" Hi there! We actually don\'t have a bug here. =) Repeated headers are governed by very specific rules from [RFC  7230 Section 3.2]url  which I\'ll reproduce here:If you make a request to with curl or in a browser you\'ll see that it repeats the header: You\'ll also see that we fold those together: This is a perfectly valid representation of this HTTP response. is itself a special case because the cookie syntax is a little ambiguous as regards that comma. This is the closest we have here to a bug: we currently join those headers with commas
column11: but really we should join them with semi-colons. If you use our cookie handling logic (e.g.
column12: ) you won\'t encounter any problems because they parse the header correctly anyway
column13: but if you were parsing cookies yourself you might encounter a problem. Otherwise
column14: we don\'t need a new header dictionary. =)"'

column10: b'b" Thanks for the thorough reply
column11: @Lukasa. Great that requests\' headers representation is not as wrong as I was afraid of. I\'d think this would be worth documenting though
column12: given that so many other libraries use a data structure which preserves multiple headers more closely to how they were sent
column13: leading other requests users to maybe ask you the same thing I did. Also worth logging a separate bug for joining multiple cookie headers with semicolons?"'

column10: b'b" I\'m open to a separate bug for the cookies with semicolons. Documenting the joint headers is strictly optional
column11: but I can see a value in having it be a note in one of the sections."'

column10: b"b' Sorry for the necro-posting...:skull: :computer: ...but... There are situationslike testing HTTP servers or APIs where sending individual headers per line is necessary (to be sure the server handles them correctly). Additionally
column11: having the option to present repeated headers one-per-line also makes things much more legible and therefore debuggable. :bug: :mans_shoe:  Any chance this could be revisited?'"

column10: b'b\' @BigBlueHat is there a reason a list of tuples is not sufficient for your use-cases? Also what do you mean "individual headers per line"?\''
b'b" I want to be able to send a request like the first example here: url  You can put all those on a single line
column11: but sometimes
column12: those lines can get quite long as in this example from the [Web Annotation Protocol]url  Concatenated that would look like: ...which is  a pain to understand. Additionally
column13: [RFC7230]url  deprecates line folding
column14: so making that prettier by wrapping it. In my specific case
column15: I\'m working on building a compliant Web Annotation Protocol server in Python and I need to verify that receiving headers on multiple lines are being received and not overwriting each  the server needs to support that (re: the above stuff). It seems Requests and most other Python client and server code build off of [rfc822.Message]url  which does support multiple headers internally
column16: but only lets you get at the first one
column17: the last one
column18: or all of them un-parsed. In short
column19: there are ways to do it
column20: but it doesn\'t bode well for HTTP accuracy in client and server code written in Python. My hope is that Requests (and by extension
column21: things like ) will support repeated headers on individual lines to make the future just that much more inviting. :sunrise: "'

column10: b'b" The second commit adds a test which tests the previously broken behavior where flags like timeout
column11: stream
column12: verify
column13: etc were lost when we used authentication. It fails without the patch. if it\'s not clear
column14: this tests by calling read() with stream turned on and off. If stream is off
column15: then the content is read ahead of time by the adapter so further reads will return an empty string. If stream is on then the content will not be read ahead of time by the adapter
column16: so the read in the test will receive the actual content. Without the patch the content is consumed by the adapter ahead of time regardless of the state of the stream flag."'

column10: b'b" Riiiight
column11: now that makes sense. This is an unforeseen problem to do with how exception tracebacks are being reported in Python 3. [PEP 3134]url  introduced this \'chaining exceptions\' reporting that you can see in @bodiam\'s traceback. The purpose of this error reporting is to highlight that some exceptions occur in blocks
column12: and to work out what chain of exceptions was hit. This is potentially very useful: for instance
column13: you can hit an exception after destroying a resource and then attempt to use that resource in the block
column14: which hits another exception. It\'s helpful to be able to see both exceptions at once. The key is that the raised as the first exception is _unrelated_ to the subsequent ones. In fact
column15: that\'s the standard control flow in  . This means that the real exception that\'s being raised here is the exception that wraps the exception being raised in  . This is _not_ a Requests bug
column16: it\'s just an ugly traceback introduced by Python 3. We can try to reduce the nastiness of it somewhat by refactoring the method in (though I don\'t believe it\'s possible: @shazow?)
column17: but that\'ll only remove the from the chain: the rest will stay in place."'

column10: b'b" Fun. IMO it\'s not worth it; we do that kind of thing in many places to distinguish between different version of Python or the platform it\'s running on. We could reduce this one instance of it
column11: but there would be many others."'

column11: and I respectfully disagree with the idea that this is a bug in Python rather than  .  Python  /  blocks are meant to be very concise and limited in scope.  By placing the entire attempt inside an block
column12: you imply that any exceptions that happen during the course of are related to your handling of the  : (see: url  You could just as easily use: This would prevent the unwanted association of connection errors with an unrelated  .  I think it would also reveal that the occurs more often than anticipated; I can\'t find any version of the Python docs that says takes any arguments

column10: b"b' Using on is widely considered bad style in Python
column11: which encourages use of EAFP (Easier To Ask Forgiveness than Permission) as a programming style. '"

column10: b'b" EAFP is indeed encouraged.  However
column11: in this case
column12: it is less explicit (thus the need for comments
column13: and the reason no one has noticed those comments are inaccurate)
column14: and it causes unrelated error exceptions to be chained to a control flow exception.  If EAFP is more important to you than those considerations
column15: that\'s your call."'

column10: b'b" The reality is that there are too many cases where doing a version check is simply not sufficient. There are tons of Python platforms and implementations out there\\xe2\\x80\\x94things like Jython
column11: PyPy
column12: AppEngine
column13: eventlet
column14: etc. In fact
column15: many of these platforms are not even stable like CPython might be\\xe2\\x80\\x94a broken feature might be a bug that gets fixed in a minor version bump which is completely incongruent with the CPython reference implementation. Eventually it just seems like it\'s safest to check if the feature is there and use it if it is
column16: regardless of what version is being advertised."'

column13: for some combinations of keys it will work

column16: clarity and performance.### Slow but compatible Change so that it sorts the keys every time it fetches an adapter. The advantage is that is still a vanilla dictionary
column17: if you consider it a public API.### A custom dictionary type Something like Django\'s which would sort the keys on insertion. The advantage is that is still a mapping and now is faster. The disadvantage is the maintenance cost of a custom data structure. Also

column19: isn\'t it?).### A list of tuples Having and as the public API for adapters
column20: we might just as well implement the sorting while mounting and just maintain as a list of tuples. The advantage is that it\'s the fastest solution with no additional maintenance burden. The disadvantage is backwards incompatibility.## We have to sort... but how exactly? This is another design issue. It appears that sorting first from the longest key to shortest

column10: b'b" I am sincerely sorry @ambv. That\'ll teach me to work from memory ever again.  Here are my thoughts about this with the code above:We could collect a list of matching adapters instead of returning the first one we find. The problem is then deciding which adapter to useWe could maintain two separate adapters registries: 1) user-created 2) default. The user-created adapters would be the first to be searched through and if there\'s a match in them we could then return that. If none of those match we would then search the default adapters and if nothing matches from there raise the error. To preserve the API we could make a property. The method would then only set adapters on the user-created dictionary. The returned information would then be best represented as a list of two-tuples where the user-created items come first and is then followed by the default. This gives an intuitive idea of the overall ordering of discovery of adapters. This

column10: b"b' [WIP] [2.0] Header keys should be native strings.'"

b'b" _Note_: This PR follows a discussion on IRC. The logs can be found [here]url ### Summary This fixes a problem that @url  _would_ have had in #1335 if the current Case-Insensitive Dict didn\'t behave so weirdly (see #1333 for progress on that). Right now
column11: Requests unconditionally encodes all header values as bytes on all Python versions. Kenneth and I are (tentatively) in agreement that header values should actually be native strings on all platforms. This pull request introduces code that explicitly encodes or decodes string objects to satisfy that requirement.### Notes Firstly
column12: **this is a breaking API change on Python 3**. On Python 2 the behaviour will be the same unless the user has changed
column13: and if they have they deserve what\'s coming to them. On Python 3
column14: all header keys on  s will go from being bytes to unicode objects
column15: and so anyone who has correctly programmed to this interface will have to change their code. Secondly
column16: this code currently uses ASCII as the codec in both directions. I think this is OK for now. I\'m pretty sure that header values should actually be Latin-1
column17: but I can understand if we want to keep the current behaviour in place. I\'m open to feedback here."'

column10: b'b" So
column11: the problem with having an async mode is that we need to decide _how_ to have the async mode. _In principle_ the way to do that is coroutine based
column12: but _in practice_ asyncio coroutines are not quite compatible with non-asyncio event loops at this time (specifically
column13: Twisted). However
column14: they are very
column15: very close. There\'s some work going on to achieve the remaining bit of standardisation we need. If we can pull that off upstream then we can look very hard at having a requests that is async-first."'

column10: b"b' @Lukasa I seem to recall it sounding like defereds (perhaps with a slight (upcoming) alteration) would be the best implementation approach for us?'"

b'b\' @kennethreitz The answer to that is _maybe_. The problem with using Deferreds is that Deferreds don\\\'t make things magically This is a problem that really needs to be approached _very_ carefully
column11: because as long as Python 2.7 is around we cannot unconditionally expect that the standard library will have an event loop inside it that we can use. That represents a concern: we need a way to execute _without_ an event loop. This is why Deferreds are attractive: they can execute in just such a manner because they\\\'re _literally_ just callback holders. So one approach here would be to write an entirely callback-based  + HTTP/2 client library that uses Deferreds (probably on top of @njsmith\\\'s [h11]url  and @python-hyper\\\'s [h2]url  We could then try to think about how we can integrate that into the various different event loops
column12: though again
column13: I\\\'m not 100% certain of how we\\\'d do that best. _Probably_ we\\\'d have to write (sigh) an event-loop abstraction layer that basically defines certain functions as returning deferreds ("data_from_network")
column14: and that then plugs into the relevant event loops. In practice
column15: though I\\\'ve said "event loops"
column16: we really only need two implementations to get started: one that implements the  "protocol" notion
column17: and one that is synchronous and blocking (so that we continue to work in the absence of an event loop). In fact
column18: we could even just start with the second one. This is one of those things that it\\\'d be really interesting to get someone like @glyph to weigh in on
column19: in part because @glyph is strongly incentivised to help us get this right (no more treq!) and in part because he\\\'s a lot smarter than me. Certainly
column20: however
column21: I\\\'d love to have a version of requests that you can either use synchronously in its current form without noticing the difference _or_ that you can use on top of ${EVENT_LOOP}. Requests provides enough goodness that we should really reimplement as little of it as possible on different platforms.\''

Or is there a motivating factor beyond that I am not aware of? @smorin \''

column10: b'b\' Well
column11: we don\\\'t _have_ to: we can do async without it by just always deferring to threads
column12: but that\\\'s kinda gross and sad for various different reasons and is also rarely what people _actually_ want. If we want to do _actual_ async then at a certain point the code _has_ to diverge. Right now the baseline code YOLOs bytes into and out of sockets like nobody\\\'s business: that\\\'s fine
column13: but it doesn\\\'t work _at all_ if you throw it into an asyncio codebase
column14: and the only way to make it work is source level changes. The net result is that you can\\\'t support _both_ an event loop _and_ a non-blocking model in the same source code: while you can retrofit a synchronous API on top of an event loop
column15: it still _requires_ the event loop
column16: which Python 2.7 doesn\\\'t give us
column17: and requests\\\' "no external dependencies" model makes tricky for us to provide.That is _substantially_ easier. At that point
column18: we can say that the asyncio event loop is the standard event loop to which we need to program. We can assert that it will always be possible to
column19: which means we can rely on having the event loop and relevant primitives in place. At that point Deferreds aren\\\'t necessary either: the synchronous APIs basically just look like this (with namespacing
column20: obviously):  \''

column10: b'b" It\'s quite possible that we shouldn\'\'t do this at all
column11: given the other priorities of the project. This is definitely evaluation phase :)"'

column10: b'b" It\'s at least an interesting exercise to try and imagine what the core of requests would look like if written in the style of h2/h11. Even if in the end it turns out to not be the best approach -it\'s certainly more complex than any of the existing examples
column11: so I guess we\'d at least learn something :-). (And hey @Lukasa
column12: what\'s this backsliding to concrete I/O APIs as soon as the problem gets more complicated? ;-)) Wildly sketching
column13: since I have no idea how the internals of requests actually look in any kind of detail: I guess the basic I/O operations that requests needs to do are to request a connection (possibly with TLS and possibly with its own hacks to the TLS handshake logic)
column14: to do reads and writes on a connection
column15: maybe to set socket options
column16: and to close a connection. And while in h2/h11 the basic state object is a Connection that manages a single socket
column17: for requests it would be a Session that manages a socket pool. And we\'d want to make it possible to wrap this in different APIs like:-(the different response classes would differ in the API they exposed for streaming reads of the response body) Since the user is going to be calling methods on individual response wrapper objects
column18: probably we want to let each of these wrappers handle the I/O coupling for each connection. So maybe the API would look something like this: I dunno
column19: maybe this is only interesting to me :-). Certainly it would be a lot of work
column20: but the result might be rather nice..."'

column10: b'b" Heh @njsmith
column11: this is a problem because you don\'t know what Requests looks like internally. =) The internals of Requests itself already _are_ very
column12: very close to the design of h2/h11: that is
column13: they almost entirely twiddle data around in in-memory objects. Unlike in aiohttp where it seems like every single  in the library touches or handles I/O in some way
column14: the vast majority of requests is function calls. The functions that either directly or transitively do I/O or that would need to be adjusted in some way are the following: : all of these transitively wrap  . : this transitively calls
column15: which actually does do I/O : this both reads and writes (using  )
column16: and so is clearly an I/O based function
column17: but mostly just uses the primitives we\'d have to work out at the lower level. : This is the _only_ top-level requests function that actually does I/O (excepting file  which don\'t count because Unix). : This does the bulk of the low-level I/O
column18: though it calls one helper function it defines on itself that is I/O-adjacent
column19: namely... : This obtains a connection object from urllib3\'s connection pool. This is going to be different in concurrent and synchronous modes because the way we wait for connections to show up will be different. In this case
column20: for requests
column21: I\'d ideally like to touch _only_ those functions. That ensures that the rest of Requests goes on functioning exactly as it does today. This reduces the churn in Requests and reduces the odds of us introducing bugs in terrible places. From my perspective
column22: the easiest way to do this is to just write on top of all of them and throw some  s in there
column23: then wrap it all in if people want to use the blocking APIs. However
column24: if we decide we need a separate blocking backend this _all_ gets way harder. In that kind of model
column25: your approach may work slightly better
column26: because it may be quite painful (and indeed impossible?) to use  s in such a way that the top-level user of requests doesn\'t have to think about them in synchronous code. In that kind of model
column27: we actually do need to write things quite differently
column28: and at _that_ point I\'m willing to discuss tearing the whole library apart to rebuild it. Otherwise
column29: I\'m extremely reluctant to do a big rewrite: there\'s just no way that we\'ll persist all the useful functionality that the library provides in its current form. =("'

column18: where the leaf coroutines yield those "io to-do objects" and then someone on the outside either services them synchronously or hands them off to some event loop.)\''

column10: b'b" If we drop Python 2 support then being tied to asyncio isn\'t any more of a problem than being tied to httplib is today; its there
column11: it\'s the de facto event loop abstraction
column12: and it covers the primary use case.  As far as I can tell the biggest advantage of moving to the model you proposed is that it\'s relatively extensible to systems that don\'t maintain the semantics of asyncio (e.g. curio). That\'s somewhat valuable
column13: but I\'m not sure it\'s worth it to drastically tear up the code.  With that said
column14: we should consider both options. We\'re so early on right now that there is literally no reason to decide on one over the other: I remain open to doing whatever provides the best API to all Requests users. "'

column10: b'b\' Ah
column11: right
column12: I\\\'m assuming that requests dropping support for python 2 is still like... 3-5 years away (is that wrong?)
column13: so the primary advantage of the model I was talking about is that it would allow a single codebase to simultaneously support a non-blocking api and a py2 with blocking io and no external dependencies api. (Plus it would be easier to test ;-)) Certainly it would be nice to have non-blocking support in the "real" requests codebase in less than 3-5 years (and also a pony).\''

b'b\' Since @Lukasa was so kind in his assessment of my abilities I figure I should weigh in pretty substantively.  (As always
column11: my estimate last month of "a couple of days" was hilariously optimistic
column12: given that I had another conference and a week of vacation to do after that...) Let me first address some of the questions around the possibility of using directly to facilitate asynchrony. There\\\'s a stand-alone version of Deferred available from <url I\\\'ve recently been added as a package index owner
column13: and we (Twisted generally) plan to actively maintain this going forward
column14: and hopefully split it out of Twisted entirely.  This is a much smaller dependency than asyncio or one of its various clones
column15: mostly due to the fact that it does not do any I/O; it\\\'s _just_ the callback abstraction.  Right now it still includes stuff like but we are probably going to remove that and leave it in Twisted proper. There are two problems that could potentially solve within  .  Let me start with the simpler one: providing a front-end for Twisted replacing  .  Whatever asynchronous solution you end up going with
column16: it should be easy enough to have a which translates whatever not-yet-available-result. The other
column17: more substantive one
column18: is providing a common abstraction between the different layers within requests to compose with each other.  @Lukasa laid out some of these layers [in this comment]url My understanding is pretty superficial
column19: but at the highest level
column20: wraps and expects it to block
column21: and then returns its result.  What you would be using for here would be to have a single return type which could stand in for "expects it to block"
column22: and anything that currently blocks could simply start returning a
column23: which would be fired by the external I/O machinery feeding bytes into it somehow
column24: h11-style. If you have to continue supporting Python 2
column25: is definitely a friendlier abstraction for this than a  -alike
column26: since  \\\'s extremely spare API is specifically designed to be a primitive that you interact with indirectly
column27: behind the syntactic convenience of  .  (I think it\\\'s still a better internal abstraction ) The question then is
column28: having retrofitted everything internally to use this new non-blocking abstraction
column29: how do you still support blocking code?  This is actually a bit more generic than just
column30: because any non-blocking approach will have the same problem
column31: but I\\\'ll discuss it in the language of because it provides an easier shorthand :).  This breaks down into two sub-problems: how do you deal with external callers calling into e.g.
column32: and how do you facilitate plugging in a blocking implementation of something that lives in the middle of the stack? For the former
column33: the answer is really simple: you just have a wrapper that lives at the edge
column36: dispatches into an event loop which just does I/O until the returned by the lower level has fired.  Doing this in a natively asynchronous program is problematic because the whole point is you want to share an event loop and you don\\\'t want to use it re-entrantly (and Twisted
column38: has never really been retrofitted all the way to make loops easy to instantiate
column39: although we\\\'ll get there one day).  But your "event loop" can just be a little function that does blocking / and stuffs the results into the underlying I/O layer; you don\\\'t need full-blown event-driven concurrency in this layer. To plug something in in the middle is a bit more complex in implementation
column40: but essentially the same conceptually: at every possible public integration point
column41: you have a wrapper for the layer below like the one I just described
column42: and you have a wrapper for the layer above which just calls the blocking thing and then wraps the result in an already-fired  ; this is sort of what [ ]url  is for. The original pioneer of the [synchronous approach]url  @radix
column43: would tell you to use his newer library
column44: [effect]url  to thread the non-blocking needle through the core of  .  And he might even be right!  This is really a matter of taste; functionally the way you\\\'d be writing code and dealing with the edges of the system where things become blocking or attach to a concrete event loop is similar.  Effect has a bit more action-at-a-distance which can be a little tricky to reason about which is by design
column45: the separation of intents and performers is one of its architectural features but which also facilitates dispatching to different backends which requests might need. I\\\'ll probably have more thoughts on this later
column46: but I should probably yield the floor at this point we\\\'ve still got 11 months before this needs to roll out

column10: b'b" What\'s happening (or at least what I\'ve seen in many cases) is that OpenSSL
column11: upon being given a password-protected certificate
column12: will prompt the user for a password. It shows up in no logs (because the prompt is directly printed)
column13: and it doesn\'t time out because it\'s waiting for a user to press enter. Needless to say
column14: it\'s cubmersome
column15: dangerous behavior when the code is running on a server (because it\'ll hang your worker with no option for recovery other than killing the process). Is there a way to make requests raise an exception in that case instead of prompting for a password
column16: or is that completely out of your control and in OpenSSL\'s hands?"'

column10: b'b" @maxnoel I\'m pretty sure this is in OpenSSL\'s hands but if you can answer @Lukasa\'s question (the last comment on this issue) it would be very helpful in giving a definite answer regarding if there was anything we can do to help."'
b'b" You can confirm OpenSSL is blocking on stdin for the passphrase from the interactive python prompt: If you\'re running from a backgrounded process
column11: I assume OpenSSL will block waiting on that input."'

column10: b'b" That\'s correct. Is there anything requests can do to prevent that from happening? Raising an exception when no password is given would be far more useful than prompting for stuff on stdin (especially in a non-interactive program)."'
b'b" I\'m afraid that I don\'t know of any way. @reaperhulk?"'
b'b" There are ways to stop OpenSSL from doing this
column11: but I\'m not sure if they\'re exposed by pyOpenSSL. Where does requests call pyopenssl to load the client cert? I can dig a bit."'

column10: b'b" I\'m going to tag in @reaperhulk as an OpenSSL expert
column11: but my understanding is that there are no APIs for OpenSSL to load PKCS#12 format certs for client certs. This means we\'d need to absolutely convert to PEM. Doing it in memory is certainly possible
column12: but at a certain point I wonder if we don\'t just want to consider this expert enough that we will delegate to whatever SSLContext you pass us."'

column10: b'b" @Lukasa Thanks for taking this issue seriously. Sorry if this sounds too technical
column11: but essentially it is just this: You want to access a service through a client certificate. Almost everywhere you get this as a file and a password (where the file is PKCS#12 encoded). In most APIs
column12: such as the Java standard library
column13: you simply give it the filename and password
column14: and are done with it. However
column15: in Python this is complicated as hell. That\'s why almost nobody does it. Instead
column16: they convert their file and password to a PEM file by hand
column17: through OpenSSL
column18: and use that file. This is administrative overhead for every user of such an application. Because they can\'t simply name the (PKCS#12) file and password. I think the library should make it at least as simple as in Java. already does a great job of simplifying stupid complex APIs
column19: and the PKCS#12 use case is just another example of a stupid complex API."'

column10: b'b" Yeah
column11: I don\'t disagree with that at all: I\'d be totally happy to have some sort of solution for PKCS#12 support somewhere in the stack. What I\'m trying to get a feel for is what code is required to make that work
column12: and as a result where this should be placed. My reasoning is like this:1. Generally speaking
column13: Requests only adds to its API surface if there is substantial utility in doing so (that is
column14: if it\'s used by lots of people or used very heavily by some)
column15: and if the thing we\'re doing is difficult to get right or has subtle edge cases.2. Normally supporting PKCS#12 would count as an addition to the API surface
column16: but if it doesn\'t change the syntax of at all (just widens the things it will support) and doesn\'t regress the behaviour (that is
column17: we can reliably tell the difference between PKCS#12 files and PEM files
column18: or we can easily just process through both chains of logic)
column19: I\'d say it counts as a sufficiently minor change to the surface that it\'s probably worth it.3. However
column20: there are other places this may go. For example
column21: at the Transport Adapter level
column22: or as a helper in the Requests Toolbelt
column23: or something else. That means I want to weigh up how subtle this is
column26: and then use that information to work out where best to put the code. For example
column27: I have a _suspicion_ right now that the standard library cannot handle PKCS#12
column28: which would mean that _at best_ Requests would only be able to use PKCS#12 with the extra installed. In an even worse case we may not have the functions available in any OpenSSL binding at all
column29: in which case we\'ll have to do some real bonkers stuff to get it to work. That\'s why I wanted @reaperhulk to weigh in: he\'ll likely be able to clarify this for us faster than I could do the research. I would like to see this support added: I just need to get some people who know what the scope of the work is to comment here and let me know how big the mountain we need to move actually is."'

b"b' @erikbern To be clear
column11: I am happy to approach and merge any solution that works somewhat consistently. For example
column12: a solution to using PKCS#12 through the PyOpenSSL contrib module in urllib3 would be acceptable. However
column13: a temporary file solution is not acceptable (as noted by @vog). This means support for PKCS#12 is unlikely to work with the standard library
column14: as the standard library module does not expose any support for it
column15: and so it will not be supported in all Requests configurations.'"

column10: b'b" So
column11: a few things:  1. I don\'t think we should take the cert keyword and expand it like this. It\'s implicitly structured data and people are already confused by the tuples in the keyword. I think continuing a known-bad pattern is foolish.  2. I think that if anything
column12: the pkcs12 adapter should be modified and upstreamed into the requests-toolbelt. I think it would be better to modify it to create the once instead of storing the pkcs12 password in memory on that object.  I think there\'s still other work that needs doing before we can handle this in the more general case no matter what and that includes determining the right API for this for Requests 3.0."'

b"b' Update host header on redirect.'"
b'b\' If you manually specify HTTP Host header
column11: any redirect to host different from specified will result in TooManyRedirects exception.  Example: After receiving first 301 response
column12: requests library makes a request for url specified in it\\\'s "Location" field (in the example above it was url  but it also preserves all headers set by user
column13: so you end up having header "Host: " while host is now **www**. Server checks "host" header and responds with 301 again. And now we\\\'re in a loop. I\\\'d be glad to add tests for this fix
column14: but httpbin does not support subdomains.\''

column10: b'b" Thanks for this! The Pull Request itself looks good. Before we merge this
column11: I want to nail down a few things because it\'s not clear to me this this fix won\'t cause people problems. In particular
column12: if you\'ve set explicitly you clearly feel that Requests is going to choose an incorrect value for that header. If you\'re then 302\'ed to the _same_ domain
column13: or with a relative URI
column14: this will overwrite your previous header with the new one which is presumably not acceptable. Is that a real problem
column15: or have I made that up?"'

column10: b"b' [WIP] Better chunked handling.'"
b'b" Following #1642
column11: I think we should treat urllib3\'s pooled connections better when we manage them ourselves. This PR provides the following extra functionality:Clean up connections when we hit problems during chunked upload
column12: rather than leaking them.Return connections to the pool when a chunked upload is successful
column13: rather than leaking it. The diff is a little unclear
column14: so let me clarify: I wrapped most of the chunked code in a block
column15: then added a catch-everything exception handler that will attempt to close the connection if we hit it. Otherwise
column16: we\'ll return the presumably-fine connection to the pool. I\'d like some code review on this. @sigmavirus24
column17: can you confirm this is doing what I think it is
column18: and can you give me some suggestions for how best to test it? @shazow
column19: if you have time
column20: can you confirm that I\'m obeying the semantics of the urllib3 connection pool? (e.g. should I check if we get a header on the response?"'

This is the sample output.*\\\\* Iteration 0 ** *\\\\* Iteration 1 ** The memory usage does not grow with every iteration

column10: b'b" May I ask why this issue has been closed?  My company has experienced this same issue
column11: which became even more augmented when using pypy.  We spent several days tracing the origin of this issue in our code base to python-requests. Just to highlight the seriousness of this issue
column12: here\'s a screenshot of what one of our server processes looked like when running a memory profiler: url  The issue is still present with regular cpython
column13: but is less noticeable. Perhaps

column15: despite the grave consequences it has for those utilizing this library for long-standing processes. At this point
column16: we are desperate enough to consider using curl with a subprocess.  Please let me know what you think and if this will ever be investigated thoroughly.  Otherwise
column17: I hold the opinion that python-requests is too dangerous to use for mission critical applications (eg: health care related services). Thanks

column17: then sets it to None. Then it closes (and sets to None) the most recent  . If you also profile

column10: b'b" So looking at this
column11: what memory_profiler is using to report memory usage is the process\' resident set size (rss). This is the size of the process in RAM (the vms
column12: or virtual memory size
column13: has to do with mallocs)
column14: so I\'m looking to see if we\'re leaking virtual memory
column15: or if we\'re just having pages allocated for memory that we\'re not losing."'

column10: b'b" So given that the all of the URLs we\'d been using thus far were using verified HTTPS
column11: I switched to using and while there\'s still a consistent increase in memory
column12: it seems that it consumes ~11-14MiB less on the whole. It still all comes back to the line (and to a lesser degree now
column13: ).  The interesting thing is that VMS doesn\'t seem to grow much when I\'m examining it in the repl. I have yet to modify mprof to return that value instead of the RSS value. A steadily increasing VMS will certainly point to a memory leak while RSS could simply be a large number of mallocs (which is possible). Most operating systems (if I understand correctly) don\'t reclaim RSS eagerly
column14: so until another application page faults and there\'s no where else to assign it from
column15: RSS will never shrink (even if it could). That said
column16: if we\'re consistently increasing without reaching a steady-state
column17: I can\'t be certain if that\'s  or just the interpreter"'

column10: b'b" I\'m also going to see what happens when we use urllib2/httplib directly because I\'m starting to think that this isn\'t our problem. As far as I can tell
column11: properly closes all sockets and removes references to them to allow them to be GC\'d. Further

column10: b'b" After running a bunch of long running benchmarks
column11: here\'s what we\'ve found:calling explicitly helps!users running multiple requests
column12: should use and properly close it after they\'re done. Please merge #2326 PyPy users are better without JIT! Or they should call explicitly! TL;DR; looks good
column13: below you will find a couple of charts running this snippet: CPython:![]url  PyPy without JIT:![]url  PyPy with JIT:![]url  I believe one of the reasons we all got confused initially is because running the benchmarks requires a bigger set to exclude the way GC behaves from one implementation to another. Also running the requests in a threaded environment requires a larger set of calls due to the way threads work (we didn\'t see any major variation in memory usage after running multiple thread pools).  In regards to PyPy with JIT
column14: calling for the same number of calls
column15: saved ~30% of memory. That is why I believe JIT results should be excluded from this discussion since it\'s a subject of how everyone tweaks the VM and optimizes the code for JIT."'

column10: b'b" Closed and reopened to get a rebuild. The code changes here look totally fine to me
