column10: b'b" Not that I\'m trying to dissuade anyone from accepting my pull request
column11: but I recognize that this is kind of a hack.  Ideally the request preparation should be protocol neutral and there would be a hook or something to wire in any protocol-specific from the adapter (where I feel it belongs). However
column12: I didn\'t really think such a convoluted shift was warranted for such a minor change of functionality."'

column10: b'b" @jvantuyl I actually disagree with that part. Requests is fundamentally a HTTP library. It\'s nice that Transport Adapters make it possible to use whole different protocols (with and being the only ones I\'ve seen done)
column11: but it\'s not actually what Requests is intended to do. When we don\'t need to make it harder we shouldn\'t
column12: but neither should we make Requests protocol-agnostic."'

column10: b'b" So I\'m personally :-1: on this because the changes here smell. Requests are fundamentally HTTP related and should stay so. All HTTP requests require a host so limiting this to and schemes just introduces one more avenue for obscure failure."'
b'b\' @Lukasa Hmmmmm
column11: I\\\'m not suggesting it needs to be entirely protocol agnostic; merely that
column12: if we\\\'re going to purport to have pluggable protocols at all
column13: we should compartmentalize them as much as reasonable. @sigmavirus24 Please describe the smell.  Am I looking for cheese or rotting meat?  Seriously though
column14: the file RFC specifies that empty hosts equate to localhost.  file:/// is perhaps the most common form of file URL that there is.  Refusing to accept that as possible is refusing the file protocol in its entirety. How do you propose to allow this work?  Back in Pull Request #1109
column15: I was told that this was "exactly the type of thing that I was hoping people would make with Connection Adapters" and that "just doesn\\\'t belong in Requests itself
column16: but another module" and "it would be awesome".  Are we making this impossible now?  That would not be awesome. Then again
column17: one man\\\'s cheese is another man\\\'s mold?  Indulge me for a minute.  Sample my cheese and see if you like the smell after tasting the flavor.  As it turns out
column18: this eliminates something phenomenally useful.  Let me explain what I actually _do_ with this code
column19: as it all comes down to two very useful things. Firstly
column20: I like to test my code.  Tested code is great.  Testing code with requests is hard
column21: because it\\\'s network-active.  Essentially
column22: you have to mock it out; which
column23: in turn
column24: makes your tests inaccurate.  When requests changes
column26: and my tests don\\\'t reflect the changes. To get good coverage
column27: this forced me to set up a mock web-API and run it on a small web server.  It made my code have environmental dependencies for testing
column28: and building the test environment was a pain.  As I developed this mock server
column29: I realized that 95% of the handlers were just returning a file. I thought to myself
column30:
Why not just use file:/// into the test directory and work with the files? That makes it self-contained, and only requires a different URL for testing, which I already do!"  That\\\'s when I implemented the file:/// URL because, well, it was easy. Secondly, I love documentation.  The more I started developing my code this way, I started to collect a battery of files.  These files were checked in with my code, contained JSON of the actual requests, and turned out to entirely document the expectations I had for the API I was interacting with.  I could even look in the git history to see when I started using a feature, etc.  It made my code much more accessible to other developers because it was so much "look here, see what it\\\'s doing". So, here are two very real benefits in very real code that are made possible by this rather modest change.  I feel that they heavily outweigh any small smell that they may cause (of course, I\\\'m biased).  This is a five-line change limiting HTTP-specific behavior to HTTP-specific protocols in a system that is architected to support additional protocols through plugins in order to support one of the other most widely-used RFC-specified protocols on the planet.  Isn\\\'t it a smell if a minor, overzealous sanity check prevents this from being attainable? If that\\\'s too much, can I just remove the checkl?  Or can I move it into the HTTP adapter so it happens later?  I don\\\'t think either of those make it more maintainable, thought they at least make things possible.\''
requests	1710	closed	7	Lukasa	2013-10-29 09:29:42	6.95			+1	b'b\' @jvantuyl In principle, sure. In practice, Requests only knows about HTTP. Everything about the Transport Adapter is totally about HTTP. If we were moving protocol-specific features to the Transport Adapter, we\\\'d just have  . =D Don\\\'t get me wrong. I\\\'m in favour of supporting URLs, which is why I\\\'m in favour of this change. I\\\'m just trying to make it clear that I\\\'ll otherwise draw a fairly strong line in the sand at "this far but no further". There is a limit to what Requests should be able to do in non-HTTP protocols.\''
requests	1710	closed	8	sigmavirus24	2013-10-29 09:29:42	473.72	+1			b'b" Lots of branches of logic smell to me, especially repeated branches of logic. That is no confident coding, that is fearful coding. Fear has a distinct smell to it which I vastly dislike.The greater context is that we have all been vastly adverse to having the protocol ever supported. I think very early on it was and it was awful and buggy. We\'ve shot down every request thus far to add it or support it. I don\'t see a reason why this should be different, but I\'ll address other issues you raise.I like to test my code to. I like to test my code so much I wrote a requests-specific tool to test it called Betamax. It\'s cool, you should check it out. This allows your request to hit the network once, record the details of the request and response and save it for playback in the future. You can match it however you like and even define your own matchers (to match on the request you\'re making). You can match in a fuzzy way or in a very strict way. There\'s a lot of freedom in it for as opinionated as it is.I check in the files (saved with JSON) of my interactions that are recorded with Betamax. I call them cassettes. Again, you should check out betamax. Finally, instead of having to change the URL you\'re requesting against, Betamax allows you to just keep requesting the same thing. If there\'s a matching request and response it will use that. If there isn\'t and you told it not to interact with the internet you\'ll get a helpful exception. If there isn\'t and you tell it that it can talk to the internet, it will record it for you! And on top of everything, it requires no changes to requests. It just works. It\'s also documented but I am not content with the documentation I\'ve written. In fact, now that I think of it, I\'m not sure I documented how to write your own matcher very well so I\'m going to go rewrite it."'
requests	1710	closed	9	sigmavirus24	2013-10-29 09:29:42	140.42			+1	b'b\' I guess what I really mean, is that your goal is achievable without these changes which may be minor but which are likely to be removed in future refactors of the code-base. As @Lukasa explained, we\\\'re really primarily concerned with HTTP and while other adapters don\\\'t run into this issue, there are probably other ways around this. One thing is that the implementation details of the Adapter are completely opaque to requests and should always be. Certainly is common among browsers and even curl, but why not do something more clever? For example, you could just as easily have your adapter receive requests on: which I\\\'m pretty sure is safe from conflict. Really, it could match on anything the user wants. If they\\\'re wrapping an API (like I am), they can add an adapter for the API they\\\'re wrapping, e.g.: This would allow the user to not need to specify when making their "mocked" requests. My last comment was not meant to sell you Betamax. Frankly here are the reasons I\\\'m :-1:The code is likely to get lost in some future shuffle. This will break your adapter then and we\\\'ll have to rehash this issue.There are other ways that don\\\'t require this changeThere are other libraries that seem to satisfy your needs and other people\\\'s needs  Betamax  requestions  vcrpy  and the list goes onHistorically we as trio have been wont to encourage people to use the scheme and to support it\''

b"b' [Suggestion] Simplify charset handling'"
b'b\' To cut to the chase
column11: here are my suggestions:Remove automatic character set detection (charade) from the libraryHave  represent the charset from the Content-Type headerMention the caveat in the documentation### Long version There seems to be a lot of confusion regarding how the property works. After getting into some trouble with it myself
column12: I searched the issues list
column13: and found a dozen or so issues
column14: all boiling down to the same mismatch between users\\\' expectations and the intent of the library designers.#147 bytecode string returned when page has charset=UTF-8#156 get_unicode_from_response does not check charsets from meta tags#592 Internal encoding detection doesn\\\'t match external chardet call#654 () ignores charset=UTF-8 and BOM#765 Chardet sometimes fails and force the wrong encoding#861 parsing encoding utf-8 page doesn\\\'t as expected#1087 Encodings from content#1150 On some pages requests detect encoding incorrectly#1546 use a default encoding in Response\\\'s text property#1589 Make sure content is checked when setting encoding#1604  returns improperly decoded text#1683  Behaviour (encoding choice) (It must be tiring to have the same conversation over and over again. I hope I\\\'m being helpful here and not just piling on). The argument seems to be:As an HTTP library
column15: requests should not know or care about HTML and META attributesRFC 2616 states that if no charset is defined
column16: text/*" media types should be regarded as ISO-8859-1 I accept both these arguments. However, the documentation seems a bit coy, saying that "Requests makes an educated guess about the encoding
column17: implying . In practice
column18: for any content with a "text" media subtype
column19: charade will not be used unless the user explicitly sets the to None before reading the property. Additionally
column20: while ISO-8859-1 can be used as a default
column21: won\\\'t it make more sense to handle that default in and not in the method? This way
column22: the property will be None if indeed no encoding is specified
column23: allowing the user to make the decision on how to proceed. If you\\\'re going to keep the property
column24: I think it should do a simple decoding if the charset is specified in the headers
column25: and throw an exception otherwise. This way is much less confusing than the state of affairs now. Additionally
column26: the documentation should contain a warning not to use it for arbitrary web pages
column27: and perhaps a code sample showing the proper way to do it.  \''

column10: b'b" You\'ve got lots of good suggestions here. I\'ll respond to some of them. In no particular order:1. should never ever ever ever throw an exception if we can possibly avoid it. Properties throwing exceptions is bad. If we were going to start throwing exceptions from I\'d want it to become  .2. Your observation that will never get called for any content with a MIME type is totally correct
column11: and by design. RFC 2616 is incredibly clear on this point.3. I am open to moving the ISO-8859-1 default to and out of  .4. I am not open to removing flexibility from  . Stripping all the functionality from
column12: as you suggest in your last point
column13: seems silly to me. If we\'re going that far
column14: we should remove altogether. has _carte blanche_ to do whatever it can to correctly decode the output. There are points of finesse here
column15: but that will always be the case. No matter what does
column16: someone will disapprove."'

column10: b'b" @Lukasa you were tricked into saying this:This is clearly the agenda of this issue as you can tell by:@itsadok clearly wants the property to disappear because issues have been filed regarding it in the past. Let me address one other thing that @Lukasa didn\'t before I add my opinion.1. charade works fairly well for well established codecs. There are new ones that subsume old ones which it doesn\'t support yet. Why? There aren\'t publicly available statistics for those encodings and that\'s what charade relies on. If you disagree with how something is being detected
column11: why not file a bug report on charade?2. That code sample is **not** the proper way to do it. Using regular expressions on HTML is insanity and is **never** the correct answer. With that addressed
column12: let me address one more theme of this issue: Because _some negligible percentage_ of all issues have been filed about _x_
column13: _x_ should be (changed|removed). One thing to note is that all the issues with numbers lower than 1000 were filed before requests 1.0 which is when the API was finalized. If there were legitimate bugs in this attribute prior to that
column14: I would be far from surprised. Also some of those issues are instead about the choice that  made. Those are not bugs in requests or but instead in the underlying support. Finally
column15: after the release of 1.0 we had a lot of issues about the change from being a property on a Response object to becoming a method. We didn\'t remove it or change it back for a good reason. It was a deliberate design decision. The attribute is quite crucial to this library
column16: especially to the method
column17: and it will likely never be removed. Can it be improved? Almost certainly. You provided a couple of good suggestions
column18: but the overall tone this issue is meant to convince the reader that it should be removed and that will not happen. Without a reasonable guess at the encoding of the text
column19: we cannot provide the user with the method which also will not go away. Simply
column20: the user is not the sole consumer of  ."'

column10: b'b" Sorry about the closing and reopening
column11: that was a mis-click. @sigmavirus24 I\'m sorry if it seems like I have an agenda. I\'m honestly just trying to help. I read through the discussions in **all** of the issues I posted. They all really seem to revolve around the same basic confusion
column12: with people expecting  to be an all-encompassing solution where in reality it is not.  Let me just clarify some misunderstandings in what I wrote.I merely meant that it should be noted that should not be used willy-nilly on arbitrary web page
column13: precisely because it avoids using charade in many places where it can be used.The function is fully copied from
column14: with the added comment by me that it doesn\'t really work in Python 3. In any case the point was that this needs to be clarified
column15: not my specific solution.This is a valid point
column16: and perhaps serves to explain the weird nature of .text. Perhaps all that is needed is a note in the documentation."'

column10: b'b" OK
column11: mea culpa. I missed the part where relies almost entirely on for charset issues. That explains some of the design
column12: and I would have phrased my post differently if I had noticed. It seems like I hit a nerve
column13: which was really not my intention. I\'m going to close the issue
column14: but there is one pun that I just have to make.The thing is
column15: it seems that in most cases where you\'d even want to access the property
column16: you would also have a text/\\\\* MIME type ( being the exception). That means that the cases where automatic charset detection is actually used are pretty rare
column17: and unpredictable for the user. _So why keep the charade?_"'

column10: b'b" Just because something _can_ be used somewhere does not mean it should be. is slow as a result of its accuracy and painstaking meticulousness. Using it when it _can_ be used as opposed to when it _must_ be used makes the performance difference in the user\'s eyes.But we never use it. It is cruft and _should_ be removed. It is the wrong way to do things.You\'re assuming everything behaves the same way and that RFCs are followed by servers. They\'re not. Charade is occasionally used. We keep it because it is essentially part of the API. Response\'s couldn\'t have an attribute if we discarded charade. We can break the API if we ever release 3.0 but until then
column11: the API is frozen except for backwards compatible changes. Also
column12: that\'s an excellent pun.I\'m going to re-open it. You made valid points as @Lukasa pointed out. It just needs to be clear that this is not any agreement about removing the property."'

column10: b'b" Heh
column11: @sigmavirus24 both have the same reactions. Neither of us thinks this issue should be closed: I reopened it just before he could! Neither of us is angry
column12: or unhappy about having this feedback. We\'re both delighted. You just can\'t tell because of the limitations of textual communication! =D The reality is that text encoding is hard
column13: everyone is doing the wrong thing from time to time
column14: and we cannot possibly please anyone. For that reason
column15: we do the best we can
column16: and then we expose the property for people who don\'t like the way we do it. You\'ve identified good issues with
column17: and I plan to fix them (unless someone else does so first). They\'re not all backward compatible
column18: so we\'ll need to sit on them for a bit
column19: but they\'re good."'

column10: b'b" I\'m strongly +0 on this change. I can see how it\'s useful
column11: but it\'s hidden away in an undocumented library function that we never planned to expose to the world
column12: so I\'m quite happy to let this change go unmerged as well. It\'s not hard to construct a User-Agent on your own. =) More importantly
column13: the code isn\'t right. This: has multiple bugs in it. Firstly
column14: if is a bytestring on Python 3 then this will cause a bug. If it\'s a bytestring in Python 2 encoded in anything other than ASCII
column15: this will also cause a bug. If we insist on doing this
column16: then is the function to use here
column17: and you must desperately avoid passing bytestrings into unicode strings. This set of problems makes me think that this function is far more complex than it\'s worth."'

Certainly they can find it on their own now but that\'s not the same as exposing it to them which would be encouraging its use. How commonly do requests users set their own User-Agent string and want it to include all of that information? Frankly I\'m not convinced it is all that frequently. That said if @kennethreitz wants this I\'m perfectly okay with it granted that it handles strings correctly (as @Lukasa already mentioned)."'

b"b' Improve API for manual redirection-following'"
b'b\' I\\\'d like to propose a bunch of bugfixes and API improvements to redirection resolution
column11: particularly when it\\\'s being done manually (i.e. on the initial  ).  These are all motivated by problems I encountered while trying to chase redirects for every single URL in the Alexa top million
column12: which
column13: as you might imagine
column14: contains an awful lot of misconfiguredness (up to and including IMAP and SMTP servers on ports 80 and 443!) The most significant change is the new method
column15: which does what it says it resolves _one_ redirect.  This turns out to be substantially more convenient for applications that need to do complicated processing on each redirect as it happens
column16: than the existing generator.  It goes along with
column17: a new property that is the canonical home for the "is this a redirect" predicate. The second most significant change is that each response in a redirection chain now has an accurate property
column18: containing all responses up to but not including itself.  As a side effect
column19: I anti-resolved issue #1898 is now always a _list_. The third most significant change is that and do not need to be passed a bunch of arguments that were already passed to the initial  ; concretely
column20: all of  \\\'s kwargs are cached on the and reused thereafter. Everything else is bugfixes
column21: generally in the service of greater robustness against Weird Shit coming off the network.\''

column10: b'b\' I\\\'ve glanced through the code review comments stuff so far
column11: and wanted to talk more generally about how this relates to our API freeze. @zackw has said in one of his comments that he believes these changes would be welcome extensions to the API for anyone who has to manually handle redirects. That\\\'s probably true. However
column12: our API freeze policy does not say that we are freezing the API "except when it\\\'ll be useful for people if it was extended". By default
column13: the Requests answer to API changes will always be "no". The reason this issue is still open and being discussed is because we think there is potentially enough value here that we want to look at it in depth. Please don\\\'t assume that we hate your PR
column14: @zackw
column15: we\\\'re just starting from a very conservative position. Next
column16: there is a question about how much affordance we should give to people who circumvent Requests\\\' redirection policy. The general Requests policy on this sort of thing (see also: objects) is that if you don\\\'t like the way Requests does it you should do it yourself. We have made concessions here in the past
column17: but not many and always under substantial duress. Again
column18: I\\\'m going to hold off more dramatic code review until @kennethreitz gives an idea of whether he\\\'s likely to want this change at all.\''

column10: b'b" I have a couple concerns. The first is that you\'re introducing yet another way for the user to set the CA bundle. You did not state that in your description. I assume you want this in order to specify the path that you would otherwise specify to as a plain string. That noted
column11: I\'m not comfortable with verify having a trinary value (its current state) let alone having 4 possible values (
column14: and dictionary of **connection** options). Let\'s be clear
column15: you are attaching these to the connection. We\'ve held in the past that these are Transport Adapter concerns. Whilst being less invasive and a less severe API change
column16: I\'m still -0. I still feel that if you have all of the information for each URL you could structure it in such a way that a custom transport adapter could use it and attach it to the connection.  The current API affords for what you want
column17: just not in the simplest way possible. Especially given Kenneth\'s hesitancy to tie requests too closely to urllib3\'s API
column18: I\'m hesitant to be positive about this. If @kennethreitz likes the change though my only request would be that you use on the verify dictionary like so: This is far better than first checking for the value first and then assigning it. Each of those assigned values will be if in fact the parameter is not provided or the dictionary is simply empty."'

column10: b'b\' OK
column11: so thanks to the capture files I have a diagnosis of "not explicitly requests\\\' fault". #### Behaviour In the hacked situation and in when using cURL
column12: the flow is as follows: In the slow case
column13: the flow is as follows: In the hang case
column14: the flow is as above
column15: except when the server tries to close the connection down it just makes up some TCP segments instead of doing the correct shutdown. For people who don\\\'t know TCP
column16: the tear-down handshake is FIN  In addition to the server totally messing up the handshake
column17: the RST packet is invalid: it contains an ACK number but doesn\\\'t have the ACK flag set. #### Diagnosis Your server doesn\\\'t play well with connection re-use _at all_. It seems to make the invalid assumption that each connection will map to a single HTTP request
column18: but doesn\\\'t enforce it by sending the header on the response. Thus
column19: requests assumes it can keep using the connection
column20: but the server just ignores it. It doesn\\\'t even close the connection itself
column21: relying on the client to do it (even though the client has no reason to do so). In addition
column22: it seems not to properly understand TCP
column23: having at least once utterly failed to tear down a connection correctly. You don\\\'t see this problem with cURL because it doesn\\\'t re-use connections. You also don\\\'t see this problem when you hack out our connection pooling
column24: because we stop re-using connections. #### Remedies Option one is to use a properly functioning webserver

b'b" Hm. One thing worth noting that by default
column11: a pool will supply additional connections despite being empty. So
column12: if you have a pool of size 10
column13: and you ask for 50 connections concurrently
column14: then it will create 50 new connections but still only return 10 of them to the pool (the rest will be closed and discarded).  I\'m not sure what Requests\' default pool size is. I suspect it might be 1. If you\'re expecting to run N concurrent requests
column15: I suggest creating a PoolManager with size N. You can also bottleneck on the pool size by using on the pool. (These are urllib3 things
column16: you\'ll need to translate them for Requests-land)."'

b'b" Update : So I found a work around for this.Basically a colleague was reading up on the issue and saw some posts about RHEL openssl support for  cipher not being 100% for whatever reason. We tried out the request to the URL by explicitly disabling ECDH ciphers (adding the negation from openssl script itself i.e. openssl s_client -connect 10.85.103.218:8443 -cipher \'DEFAULT:!ECDH\') We were able to successfully connect. Here\'s the default cipher list for the openssl on ubuntu 14.04ECDH+AESGCM:DH+AESGCM:ECDH+AES256:DH+AES256:ECDH+AES128:DH+AES:ECDH+HIGH:DH+HIGH:ECDH+3DES:DH+3DES:RSA+AESGCM:RSA+AES:RSA+HIGH:RSA+3DES:!aNULL:!eNULL:!MD5 So with that knowlege
column11: I used pyopenssl to print out my default SSL ciphers and explicitly removed every ECDH cipher from the string. Did this right in the block to import urllib3 from requests package (i.e. before starting to make any actual requests) here\'s something similar : url  I realize there may be security risks for this action but at least this gets us going and sheds more light on it. Why those particular ciphers appear to be an issue for the RHEL
column12: I have no idea. I will try when i have more time to see what particular RHEL changes may have introduced this and read up on the purpose more. Anyone know more about ciphers generally?"'

column10: b'b" The certificate won\'t usually cause this problem: this problem is caused by the *server* hanging up on us
column11: so usually it\'s the result of a cipher suite mismatch. In this case
column12: that\'s exactly what\'s going on [as you can see here]url This is a server that
column13: frankly
column14: should never be exposed to the open internet. There are no secure methods of communicating with this server: none
column15: zero. This is why the handshake fails: Requests only accepts modern cipher suites
column16: and there are no modern cipher suites available to this server. The *best* option is
column17: an option we removed because it is vulnerable to practical attacks on large-scale data transfer.  If this server is yours
column18: *please* upgrade it to a better TLS implementation or change the settings. Otherwise
column19: my first bit of advice is to reconsider ever speaking to this server. If you must

column10: b'b" @bochecha Nothing breaks without a change. _Something_ in your environment has changed. There are a few options:1. Your code has changed. The Python import system is fragile and weirdly global. To work this out
column11: do a binary search through your commits until you can find the breakage. The advantage of this is that it should be easily reproducible on more or less any system.2. Your dependencies have changed. You appear to have pinned Requests: have you pinned everything else? Check whether any of your dependencies have pushed updates recently.3. Your OS has changed. Do you control your OS image on Codeship? Basically: code that is exactly the same doesn\'t just magically change. Given that the one thing you definitely _haven\'t_ changed is Requests
column12: I think it\'s safe to say that Requests should not be the first place you look for problems. =D"'

That explains why things started failing this morning: the CI somehow updated pytest this morning in its virtualenv (it usually uses a cached version of the virtualenv).  tl;dr: **It seems requests==2.6.0 doesn\'t work with pytest==3.0.2.** Leaving it here in case it can help someone else in the future. /me goes and upgrades all the deps :wink: "'

column10: b"b' Hmmm seems to time out right away if you make the request over HTTP. here is my investigation so far. url  About to start reading code.'"
b'b" So... this is an error.  The gist of it is
column11: with HTTPS connections connect() gets called earlier in the urlopen() process than with a HTTP connection. Specifically
column12: for HTTPS _new_conn will call _prepare_conn
column13: which calls connect() on the socket
column14: where for HTTP
column15: the connect() call is delayed all the way until . urllib3 sets the connection timeout until after calling _get_conn
column16: but before
column17: which explains why the timeout isn\'t set. The obvious question is why isn\'t this an issue when you\'re not using a proxy? Well
column18: prepare_conn only attempts the connect() if you\'re using a proxy
column19: with the following note: I\'ll discuss with @shazow and see if we can figure out a good course of action."'

b'b" I\'ve just hit this issue too in Python requests 2.8.1. In my case I\'m making a large number of periodic https requests to a apache2 server with connection keep-alive timeout 5s. There is a race between the server closing a timed out persistent connection and the client making a request on the same connection. Given a bit of network latency the client can often attempt to send a request on the socket before it gets notified it as been closed. Given my application (testing an API) I\'m going to handle the specific exception that results with a retry or two."'

column10: b'b" Hrgh. Whatever web server you\'re talking to is not very good. You see
column11: requests will percent-encode data when sent using the dictionary form
column12: so that the underlying string ends up looking like this:  . That\'s the correct form for data that is form-urlencoded: it\'s the _urlencode_ part of the thing! However
column13: your server seems to want data that _advertises_ itself as form-urlencoded but _is not_ form-urlencoded. Your best bet
column14: then
column15: is going to be to continue to manually set the header yourself: the web server is just being stupid."'

column10: b'b" So this is sort of a bug with that import machinery and sort of a bug with python 2 and sort of a bug with chardet. On the bright side
column11: there\'s a fix for it that can be performed in chardet and then vendored into requests
column12: etc. On the not-so-bright side
column13: this _can_ affect urllib3 as well. I was trying to debug url  with pdb to figure out why I was seeing a different error and ran into an issue with this import logic trying to import because on Py2
column14: is treated as a implicit relative import first and then a non-relative import second. (Woo
column15: thanks Python 2.) The temporary work-around was to add to the top of the file I was trying to debug in. This
column16: of course
column17: could be applied to urllib3 and chardet both. I think the better option is to attempt to fix the import machinery stolen wholesale from pip. @dstufft definitely understands this code better than I do
column18: but as I understand it now: we stop trying to import it at L83 if the (which in these cases are and  ) fails. Instead
column19: I think we need to figure out how to try one last case to actually mimic the regular import machinery. I can imagine more complex import failures
column20: like seeing something like fail
column21: so something like Does that make sense?"'

column10: b'b" Further intrigue
column11: pyinstaller places meta-path modifiers into so debugging into shows: I think the existence of those Importer objects is preventing the default Python behaviour from taking over. (In other words
column12: Python is attempting to do a module local import before doing an absolute import and those meta_path modifiers are preventing it from working as expected.) So there are two options here:1. Update requests
column13: chardet
column14: and urllib3 to add to the top of each submodule (annoying but in general just a good idea and will help with Py2/Py3 import behaviour compatibility).2. Start down the rabbit hole I had started chasing the first time. Develop an algorithm that continuously tries to import an algorithm. Right now we do the following: Given a name
column15: e.g.
column17: try to import that If that fails
column18: strip from the name and try to import that If that fails
column19: give up  We could modify that to instead then attempt to strip or from the name but then something like  . I have some more experimentation that I\'d like to play with
column20: before acting on either of these
column21: but I strongly prefer option 1."'

column10: b'b" So the simplest solution
column11: although not one I like best
column12: is to insert the into the first position of (e.g.
column13: ) and the resulting script behaves the same with (this slightly modified) 2.6.0 as with 2.5.0. That said
column14: I\'m still in favor of 1. although it seems far less necessary."'

column10: b'b\' So I read a bit of the PEP that explains the part plays and talked to @dstufft a bit on IRC. Provided the way PyInstaller registers it\\\'s import hooks on the meta path you can see that it registers it\\\'s "BuiltinImporter" first. Since the first hook to return a module wins
column11: we probably want to register our hook first. This allows Python 2\\\'s behaviour of try an implicit relative import then try an absolute import to kind of just work. As a quick fix
column12: I\\\'m going to change our behaviour from appending to the meta path to inserting at the start of it. We kind of want that behaviour anyway.\''

b'b" Over in the [Apache Tika Python Port]url  I\'m noticing in [tika-python#44]url  and in [tika-python#58]url  some odd behavior with requests on Python 2.7.9. For whatever reason
column11: when using a file handle and putting it with  it blocks and blocks until finally it gets (correctly) a BadStatusLine back after a timeout. Anyone else seen this?"'

column10: b'b" Any requests call that uploads a request body will send the entire body before attempting to read the response. That means that
column11: if the remote end does not close that connection abruptly (throwing an Exception on our end)
column12: we\'ll block until the response has been entirely sent. Sadly
column13: we don\'t support the 100-continue flow at this time (because httplib has no way of letting us see what\'s going on there)
column14: so it\'s difficult for us to do anything else."'

column10: b'b" @chrismattmann so there\'s (as you could guess) a significant difference in behaviour between those two test cases. When you just give us the raw data as a string
column11: we write it all at once. When you give us an open file descriptor
column12: we pass it down to  . What httplib then does with it is read 8192 bytes (yes 8 KB) at a time and write it to the socket to stream it. **Note** this is not the same as a chunked upload. I suspect that Tika server doesn\'t like getting such small amounts over a period of time."'

column10: b"b' If you want to test sending larger chunks (by forcing httplib to send what it reads) you could tinker with url  to wrap your file to see if uploading more at once will aid this.'"
b'b" OK
column11: here is some more info. If I use something like: Works as expected (however it makes Tika server get a 415 b/c for whatever reason Content-Type isn\'t passed in the HTTP request). However: still fails."'

column12: \'r\') works fine on Linux
column13: e.g.

column10: b'b" Ahh
column11: quick insight too
column12: the 415 error request on Tika server is caused by the following content type passed: (-data;boundary=d764925698424d719281a56941edb9b7). So it seems that files={\'filename\'
column13: open(filename
column14: \'r\')} causes a multi-part request using PUT; however
column15: data=open(filename
column16: \'r\') doesn\'t. Full Tika Server stack trace:  "'

column10: b'b" sorry about that. I just thought providing more information would help. I\'ll stop spamming now while I continue to try and debug this."'
b'b" As an FYI
column11: I don\'t consider this issue . It\'s unclear to me where the precise error here is seems to be either in the way that requests generates PUT HTTP requests when passing data=open(\'filename\'
column12: \'r\') (which doesn\'t work on Windows when contacting Jetty from Tika Server on localhost) compared to the way it generates PUT HTTP requests when doing files={\'filename\' : open(\'filename\'
column13: \'r\')} (which works on Windows when contacting Jetty from Tika Server on localhost). I\'ve seen things debugging around that Jetty by default uses Memory mapped IO which locks files on Windows. Not sure if that\'s the root cause of the issue here or not. Anyways wanted to share that."'

column10: b'b" To be clear
column11: the root cause of the issue is likely to be in
column12: or possibly even lower (e.g. WinSock). Requests simply doesn\'t have a separate code path here."'

column11: no it doesn\'t: it points the problem at tika-python. Observe the following in my Windows Python prompt: This is a thoroughly amusing problem! Anyone got a guess about what\'s going wrong here? I\'m going to leave a nice big white block while you think about it
column12: because the answer is unexpected. It\'s universal newlines. Universal freaking newlines. Check it out: When you pass the file handle into us
column13: we ask the filesystem how many bytes there are. It says: 403. But
column14: when you pass it through Python
column15: it _kindly_ strips the from each line
column16: causing us to lose a few bytes. When you passed us the string this didn\'t matter
column17: because we only checked how long the string was
column18: but when you pass us a file handle it all goes wrong. The solution? Add one character to in to ensure that you open the file as
column19: not  ."'

column10: b'b" We see this use case when using Ironic bare-metal provisioning in the OpenStack project to provision a system from scratch. So the underlying temporary installation OS isn\'t really configured with proxies in mind. I have not heard of \'per-host proxies\' before. So unsure if that would work or not."'
b"b' The per-host proxies feature is mentioned in our changelog for 2.8.0
column11: but it allows you to set up a proxies dictionary like so: This will only use the proxy for requests to  : other requests will not use the proxy.'"

column10: b'b" Unfortunately we don\'t have a good idea which hosts we will be accessing. Thus want the more general method."'
b'b" So you don\'t know what hosts you _will_ access
column11: just which ones you mustn\'t? It does feel like you should be setting the environment variable
column12: so that other tools obey these rules too."'

column10: b'b" Right. So this installation OS is thrown away when done. So doesn\'t have the variables set.  All the work is done by the Ironic Python Agent
column11: which is a Python program. Our current plan is to just use [\'no_proxy\'] = \'....\'  but that seems a little hackish but will work. Thus why I filed this RFE. I\'d be happy to try to come up with a pull-request
column12: given a few pointers on what to modify."'

column10: b'b" I think we could do it easily enough
column11: but I\'m increasingly reluctant to add further features to the already quite complicated proxy logic. In the short term
column12: your solution will work. Longer term
column13: I need to think about where the line is with further proxy features."'

b"b' Test socket server'"

b'b" Fixes #2866.### What is this? This is an implementation of a basic socket server that is able to run concurrently with the main thread. This might be useful for testing our \'Transfer-Encoding: chunked\' functionality as pytest-httpbin isn\'t able to handle this kind of encoding.### How does it work? You provide the Server constructor with a handler that will be called once the socket server is listening. This handler will be able to accept clients and send and receive any info it wants to. The main thread will be able to query the server by creating a normal socket. ### Syntax proposed I think that using a Context-Manager is a great way of making it easy to use the Server. ### Doubtsurllib3 tries to use a IPv6 socket and falls back to IPv4 when it can\'t. Should I try doing the same thing?I made a new directory for dummyserver
column11: but don\'t know whether that was the right thing to do.I am not sure whether I\'m testing my code properly. Is this a good idea? Or should I stop doing this right now?"'

b"b' Consider using system trust stores by default in 3.0.0.'"
b'b" It\'s been raised repeatedly
column11: mostly by people using Linux systems
column12: that it\'s annoying that requests doesn\'t use the system trust store and instead uses the one that certifi ships. This is an understandable position. I have some personal attachment to the certifi approach
column13: but the other side of that argument definitely has a reasonable position too. For this reason
column14: I\'d like us to look into whether we should use the system trust store by default
column15: and make certifi\'s bundle a fallback option. I have some caveats here:1. If we move to the system trust store
column16: we must do so on _all_ platforms: Linux must not be its own special snowflake.2. We must have broad-based support for Linux and Windows.3. We must be able to fall back to certifi cleanly. Right now it seems like the best route to achieving this would be to use [certitude]url  This currently has support for dynamically generating the cert bundle OpenSSL needs directly from the system keychain on OS X. If we added Linux and Windows support to that library
column17: we may have the opportunity to switch to using certitude. Given @kennethreitz\'s bundling policy
column18: we probably cannot unconditionally switch to certitude
column19: because certitude depends on cryptography (at least on OS X). However
column20: certitude could take the current privileged position that certifi takes
column21: or be a higher priority than certifi
column22: as an optional dependency that is used if present on the system. Thoughts? This is currently a RFC
column23: so please comment if you have opinions. /cc @sigmavirus24 @alex @kennethreitz @dstufft @glyph @reaperhulk @morganfainberg"'

column10: b'b\' I think the system trust stores (or not) essentially boils down to whether you want requests to act the same across platforms
column11: or whether you want it to act in line with the platform it is running on. I do not think that _either_ of these options are wrong (or right)
column12: just different trade offs. I think that it\\\'s not as simple on Windows as it is on Linux or OSX (although @tiran might have a better idea). I _think_ that Windows doesn\\\'t ship with all of the certificates available and you have to do something (use WinHTTP?) to get it to download any additional certificates on demand. I think that means that a brand new Windows install
column13: if you attempt to dump the certificate store will be missing a great many certificates. On Linux
column14: you still have the problem that there isn\\\'t one single set location for the certificate files
column15: the best you can do is try to heuristically guess at where it might be. This gets better on Python 2.7.9+ and Python  3.4+ since you can use to get what the default paths are
column16: but you can\\\'t rely on that unless you drop 2.6
column18: and 3.3. In pip we attempt to discover the location of the system trust store (just by looping over some common file locations) and if we can\\\'t find it we fall back to certifi
column19: and one problem that has come up is that sometimes we\\\'ll find a location
column20: but it\\\'s an old outdated copy that isn\\\'t being updated by anything. People then get really confused because it works in their browser
column21: it works with requests
column22: but it doesn\\\'t in pip. I assume the fall back to certifi ensures that things will still work correctly on platforms that either don\\\'t ship certificates at all
column23: or don\\\'t ship them by default and they aren\\\'t installed? If so
column24: that\\\'s another possible niggle here that you\\\'d want to think about. Some platforms
column26: don\\\'t ship them by default at all. So it\\\'s possible that people will have a requests using thing running just fine without the FreeBSD certificates installed
column27: and they then install them (explicitly or implicitly) and suddenly they trust something different and the behavior of the program changes. Anyways
column28: the desire seems reasonable to me and
column29: if all of the little niggles get worked out
column30: it really just comes down to a question of if requests wants to fall on the side of "fitting in" with a particular platform
column31: or if it wants to prefer cross platform uniformity.\''

column10: b'b" I wouldn\'t say that either option is _completely_ wrong
column11: but I do think that using the platform trust store is significantly right-er
column12: due to the availability of tooling to adjust trust roots on the platform and the relative unavailability of any such tooling for requests or certifi.  If you go into Keychain Access to add an anchor (or the Windows equivalent) nothing about requests makes it seem like it would be special
column13: that it would be using a different set of trust roots than you had already configured for everything else."'

column10: b"b' It depends if your audience are people who are familiar with a particular platform or not. I have no idea how to manage the trust store on Windows but I know how to manage the trust store for requests because requests currently chooses being internally consistent cross platform over being externally consistent with any particular platform.  IOW this change makes it easier for people who are familiar with the system the software is running on at the cost of people who are not.  Sent from my iPhone'"
b'b" In the abstract
column11: I disagree.  Of course
column12: we may have distribution or build toolchain issues which make people have to care about this fact
column13: but if it works _properly_ ( s without argument
column14: doesn\'t require C compiler shenanigans for the end user) then what is the penalty to people who are not familiar with the platform?"'

column10: b"b' It forces them to learn the differences of every platform they are running on.  Sent from my iPhone'"

b'b" So I am in favour of using the system store in general because in most cases [outside of dev] if you\'re relying on requests or a similar library you\'re going to expect it to work similar to the rest of the . Asking someone to learn the tooling for the system they are deploying on is not unreasonable. If an application uses requests and needs to trust a specific cert (end-user story here)
column11: it is usual that it\'ll handle the installation for that platform at install time (aka OS X or Windows).  From a developer perspective
column12: it becomes a little more difficult but still not insurmountable as long as we approach this in a way that the developer has clear methods to continue with the same behaviour as today. As discussed in IRC
column13: perhaps the easiest method to ensure sanity is to really finish up and polish certitude(? was this the tool discussed?) so we can encapsulate the -specifics clearly and try and ensure requests logic is the same on all of the platforms."'

column10: b'b" How so? By default
column11: it ought to get the trust roots you expect on every platform. It\'s not like I need to learn new and exciting things when I launch Safari vs. IE just to type  ..."'

b'b" Frustratingly
column11: I can\'t find an API that just tells it to grab the certificate store; it seems that verifying a certificate chain that you don\'t have the root to is the only way that it adds certificates
column12: and it adds them one at a time as necessary.  It baffles me that Microsoft seems to consider storage for certificates a scarce resource."'

column10: b'b" In my experience with pip
column11: which attempts to discover the system store and if it can\'t find it falls back to a bundled copy
column12: I have had to learn how the system store works on platforms that I have no intention on ever running. This is for a fairly simple method of detection (look for file systems) but it absolutely ends up that way. The simple fact is
column13: in my experience most people have absolutely no idea how their system manages a trust store (and if it manages a trust store or not).  Sent from my iPhone"'

column10: b"b' Look for files on the system*'"
b'b\' FWIW
column11: If I could prevent downstream redistributors from forcing pip to use the system store
column12: I would revert the change to look in system locations immediately and only ever use a bundled copy. The UX of that tends to be so much nicer
column13: the only reason we started to trust the system trust stores is because redistributors do patch pip to use the system trust store
column14: so you end up in a situation where people get different trust stores based on where their copy of pip came from (which is likely also a concern for requests). As an additional datapoint
column15: if I remember correctly
column16: the browsers which are _not_ shipped with the OS tend to not use the system trust store either. According to Chrome\\\'s [Root Certificate Policy]url  they will use the system trust store on OSX and on Windows but they won\\\'t use it on Linux. I believe that even where Chrome does use the system store
column17: they still layer their own trust ontop of that to allow them to blacklist certificates if need be. I assume this capability is in place because they do not wholly trust the OS trust stores to remove compromised certificates. If I recall correctly
column18: Firefox does not use the system trust store at all on any OS. Another question is what even is the "root trust store" on a Linux. The closest that you can get is wherever the system provided OpenSSL (assuming they even provide OpenSSL) is configured to point to. However AFAIK there is no way to determine if you\\\'re using a system provided OpenSSL or a copy that someone installed (perhaps via Anaconda?)
column19: the additional copy may have stale certificates or no certificates available. If it\\\'s stale certificates
column20: then you\\\'ve successfully lowered the security of requests user\\\'s by attempting to follow the system trust store. If it\\\'s an empty trust store
column21: how do you determine the difference between "empty because I trust nothing" and "empty because my copy of OpenSSL isn\\\'t shipping them" or do I have to manage the certificates I trust using my OS
column22: unless I want to trust nothing then I have to manage the certificates I trust using requests? I\\\'ve also found that talks about trying to use the platform certificate trust store on Linux (see [here]url  I\\\'ve not personally verified the information in this article
column23: however it makes me feel very wary about trying to make using the system trust store anything but an exercise in frustration. \''

column10: b'b\' I think our current approach is the correct one
column11: considering who Requests was built for.  That being said
column12: it wouldn\\\'t hurt to add more  around using system certs for "advanced" users. \''

column10: b'b" I think talking about configurability is maybe a red herring.  It\'s useful \\xe2\\x80\\x93 necessary even \\xe2\\x80\\x93 in certain circumstances
column11: but users who know they need that can usually figure it out. The more significant issue is that trust root database updates
column12: especially for end-user client software
column13: are both infrequent and extremely important to do in a timely manner.  has no mechanism for automatically updating.  Not only will it not come down in a system update
column14: it can\'t even be done globally; you have to do it once per Python environment (virtualenv
column15: install
column16: home directory
column17: etc
column18: where it\'s installed)."'

column10: b"b' @glyph I think you may have hit the nail on the head there. That is a significant reason (and addresses the other issues outlined) to use a more centralized location for the cert store.'"
b'b" The flip side is that you have trust stores like Debian which trusted CACert for a long time
column11: and still trusts SPI even though neither of those have gone through any sort of real audit that you\'d expect for a trusted CA."'

column10: b'b" As I understand it
column11: Microsoft trusts their own CA
column12: too
column13: and Apple trusts theirs.  SPI is just Debian\'s version of that
column14: isn\'t it?"'

column10: b'b" SPI isn\'t run by Debian
column11: it\'s a third party organization similar to that of the Software Freedom Conservancy that Debian happens to be a member of. It\'d be more like Microsoft and Apple trusting the CA of their datacenter just because they happened to use them as their data center. In addition
column12: I\'m pretty sure that Apple and Microsoft have both passed a WebTrust audit for their root CAs."'

column10: b'b" To be fair to Debian
column11: I think the _current_ plan is to stop using SPI certificates for their infrastructure and switch to more generally trusted certificates and then stop including SPI and switch to using just the Mozilla bundle without any additions. That being said
column12: is it even true that they are shipping updates to them? Looking at [ for the ca-certificates packages]url  it shows that the versions there are:squeeze (oldoldstable):  wheezy (oldstable):  jessie (stable):  stretch (testing):  sid (unstable): I haven\'t looked at the actual _contents_ of these packages
column13: but the version numbers lead me to believe that they are not infact keeping the ca-certificates package up to date. In addition to that
column14: looking at the open bugs for ca-certificates there are bugs like [#721976]url  which means that the ca-certificates store includes roots which are not valid for validating servers and are only valid for other topics (like email) which means you can\'t actually use the current ca-certificate package without massaging it to remove those certificates yourself. Another issue [#808600]url  has Comodo requesting a removal of a particular root that they no longer consider to be inscope for the CAB Forum\'s Baseline Requirements. That has been removed from testing and sid
column15: but has not been removed from jessie
column16: wheezy
column17: or squeeze. The maintainers of ca-certificates claim they\'ll be requesting an upload to jessie and wheezy
column18: but not to squeeze (which still has LTS suport). That\'s just from spending a little bit of time looking at one
column19: fairly popular
column20: distribution. I imagine the long tail of the issues with the system provided bundle gets worse the further away from the popular distributions you get. It\'s not clear to me that it\'s a reasonable assumption that the certificates included in any random OS are going to be properly maintained. The other elephant in the room is we\'re just assuming that because an update is available to their ca-certificates package that someone is going to have pulled it in. As far as I know
column21: most (if not all?) of the Linux systems do not automatically update by default and require configuration to start to do so. There is likely to be a bigger chance of this with Docker in the picture. On the flip side
column22: I think people generally try to update to the latest versions of their dependencies when working on a project."'

column10: b'b" Debian\'s cert bundle is almost certainly like ubuntu\'s
column11: which does not update to the Mozilla bundle that removed 1024-bit roots in order to avoid the pain like that which hit certifi. All of the out-of-date cert bundles are OpenSSL pre 1.0.2
column12: which means they cannot correctly build the cert chain to a cross-signed root without having the 1024-bit cross-signing root still present. I suspect that\'s the real concern there."'

column10: b'b" Maybe they should stop shipping an OpenSSL that can\'t correctly validate certificate chains."'

column10: b'b\' That is very nearly impossible. The issue there is that there are three major platforms (Windows
column11: OS X
column12: other)
column13: each of which ships with their own "OS-default" library for validating TLS certificate chains. For obvious reasons
column14: these libraries all also believe they are in charge of doing the TLS record building and handshaking and all the other fun stuff. That means that integrating with those libraries requires writing three separate wrapper libraries
column15: each of which may fail in exciting and different ways. Getting those to function together correctly would be extremely difficult. Even if we could do that
column16: I rolled all the "other" platforms together because they\\\'d provide OpenSSL
column17: but in fact many would either not provide that (e.g. BSD providing LibreSSL) or the user would prefer we used a different library (GnuTLS
column18: PolarSSL
column19: NSS). It should be noted that
column20: as far as I can tell
column21: literally the only piece of web software that attempts to do this is [curl]url  not even web browsers try. Firefox bundles its own TLS library (NSS)
column22: as does Chrome (BoringSSL)
column23: while Safari and Edge do not run across multiple platforms and so can stick their hooks into the OS-provided libraries. Even curl does not appear to hook into Windows\\\' default store. Currently the assumption is that any change here would simply adjust to use a PEM bundle provided by the OS. On *nix
column24: this should be in one of a few well-known locations
column25: and certitude could simply proxy to it. On OS X
column26: we can extract the certificates from the keychain and write them into a PEM file: this is what certitude does today. On Windows we could _in principle_ do this
column27: but there\\\'s some trickiness about the fact that Windows dynamically fetches some root certificates (a truly mind-boggling design decision).\''

column10: b'b" Debian and CentOS aren\'t broken. On both systems the configuration works fine with SSL_CTX_set_default_verify_paths(). Only one of both CAfile and CApath must work for SSL_CTX_set_default_verify_paths(). The patch tried to outsmart the system and work around the default API. Also requests can\'t handle CAfile and CApath at the same time. The combination caused the bug. I understand @dstufft motivation for the heuristic. OpenSSL doesn\'t report if SSL_CTX_set_default_verify_paths() has loaded any certs or has found a CApath with valid certs. For CAfile () helps but for CApath you are lost. certifi isn\'t an option. At best it\'s a matter of last resort for pip. "'

column10: b'b" Isn\'t this problem already solved in Python 2.7.10+?urllib2 can verify certificates out-of-the-box.Why can\'t _requests_ use the same solution?"'
b'b\' @shypike Let\\\'s clear some things up. =) Firstly
column11: requests can and does verify certificates out of the box
column12: and has been doing so for years: much longer than the standard library
column13: and much more effectively. The question is not "should we verify certificates"
column14: it\\\'s "how should we verify certificates". Secondly
column15: no
column16: this problem is not solved in Python 2.7.10+. In those versions of Python
column17: the standard library modules use the object returned from  . That function calls [ ]url  Unfortunately
column18: it turns out that is a relatively deficient method. It suffers from some flaws. Firstly
column19: it only handles two cases: Windows
column20: and all other platforms. On Windows it uses the method
column21: which ends up calling into  . It grabs those certificates and passes them into OpenSSL to do the verification. This has two problems: firstly
column22: it means that the certificate verification logic is _different_ between Python and
column23: for example
column25: because a different library is used to construct the certificate chain and validate the certificates. Secondly
column26: not all root certificates will be available to Python when this method is called
column27: because SChannel occasionally _dynamically fetches_ root or intermediate certificates on-demand. This leads to unexpected
column28: tricky behaviour. One of the "other platforms" that Python ignores is Mac OS X. On this platform
column30: because Mac OS X has a complex keychain system that allows substantial editing of trust. However
column31: OpenSSL pays absolutely no attention to this distinction
column32: which means that a user will be in one of three cases:1. They\\\'ll be using the built-in OpenSSL
column33: OpenSSL 0.9.8zg. This version calls into the OS X cert store to do the validation
column34: so it\\\'s the most likely to get the right answer
column35: but it\\\'s also unsupported and by-default insecure and should never be used.2. They\\\'ll be using an OpenSSL shipped with Python. If they do this
column36: it\\\'s not clear where that OpenSSL will get its certificates from: probably nowhere.3. They\\\'ll be using an OpenSSL installed from Homebrew or somewhere equivalent. These places usually copy all the certificates out of the keychain _at the time of install_
column37: but then do no refreshing of the cert store. This means that if OS X subsequently pushes out an update removing one of the root certificates from the store
column38: this change will not propagate to the verifier
column39: which will continue to trust the cert. Additionally
column41: OS X\\\'s  has a very complex and different validation logic than OpenSSL has. For example
column42: users can mark certificates as trusted for only specific websites
column43: or trusted only for specific uses: OpenSSL will not respect those distinctions. As a result
column44: the only platforms on which this is "solved" by the standard library are ones that ship OpenSSL by default
column45: compile it such that points to the right places
column46: and that appropriately configure their trust stores. That amounts to meaning some Linuxes
column47: and some other Unix-based OSes. That is officially not good enough. Right now requests is doing better than the standard library because it carefully polices trust on _all_ platforms
column48: not just the ones the standard library deigns to support. This issue is about whether we can do _even better_ by allowing the platform-specific logic to take over on  X
column49: and then as a result transitioning to use the default certificate stores on all platforms. To be clear: we will _never_ take a decision here that leads to a preference for Unix-like operating systems. That kind of parochial thinking is what leads to Windows users feeling like second-class citizens in the Python community. My current thinking here is that I\\\'d like to emulate Chrome: use OpenSSL to perform the actual TLS
column50: but have the platform-native libraries do the validation if possible. That gets us the closest to "native" behaviour on the platform in question.\''

column10: b'b" @mwcampbell PyOpenSSL does _not_ support this
column11: and never will
column12: because PyOpenSSL is a thin wrapper library around OpenSSL
column13: and so doesn\'t support the relevant APIs. However
column14: I recently got merged into cryptography the relevant bindings for OS X (#2683)
column15: and I believe that a cryptography with that change in it has been released now. I\'ve also used those bindings to successfully use OS X to validate a certificate chain. A similar approach can probably be used on Windows and the cryptography developers have expressed a willingness to bind the appropriate functions. Given that PyOpenSSL depends on cryptography
column16: this is far and away the simplest route. My current proposal is to add the relevant functionality into the urllib3 PyOpenSSL shim. I\'ve briefly discussed this with @shazow
column17: who was open to the idea. Then
column18: urllib3 would allow to take a parameter (
column19: defaulting to  ) that will automatically use the system trust store instead of OpenSSL on the relevant platforms. The question then would become whether the requests project can come to consensus on setting that parameter to  . =) We should burn that bridge when we get to it: for now
column20: I\'d like to get the building blocks in place. In an ideal world we\'d actually pull the OS-specific logic out into its own library
column21: so that it can be meaningfully tested
column22: but that\'s a pretty tricky goal. On the other hand
column23: if we can pull it off then we have both provided a really useful service to the Python community in general _and_ potentially helped move towards #2118 by providing a PyOpenSSL equivalent. This I think would be my preferred outcome."'

column10: b'b" My main concern with this discussion is the potential impacts proposed solutions could have on the user experience. So
column11: to be clear
column12: here are some guidelines: ## GuidelinesInstallation of Requests cannot require any compilation
column13: and should require no external dependencies.The porcelain API should not need to be changed in any way to accommodate these changes
column14: except to provide new functionality. Accommodating SSL is often where HTTP clients fall apart
column15: and the user experience gets compromised in the name of security. Requests\' current solution is an excellent one
column16: though not perfect. With it
column17: we were able to bring seamless proper TLS verification to countless developers that would not have used it otherwise. Any suggested improvements to this approach need to have these design goals in mind. "'

b'b" @glyph I just don\'t like anything about it
column11: and it raises every red flag in my book. It will take a currently very simple implementation of very reliable behavior
column12: and replace it with very a complicated implementation (perhaps just complex \\xe2\\x80\\x94 I personally avoid this layer at all costs
column13: hence the simplicity of the current implementation
column14: so this all seems quite complicated to me) with behavior that I fear may be far less reliable
column15: in the name of security. So ensuring the same level of reliability is my number one concern. Zero user-facing changes to installation behaviors are my second concern (NO compilation acceptable
column16: and external dependencies should also be absent). My third concern
column17: which is a large one
column18: is that Requests will now behave differently on different systems \\xe2\\x80\\x94 avoiding this was an explicit design decision when I designed it. So
column19: my reservations are large
column20: and many. But
column21: I\'m open to it
column22: tentatively. Everyone else cares about security far more than I do. I want to support that
column23: but not at any expense to the above mentioned aspects of this project. "'

column10: b'b" @tmehlinger I don\'t want to sound rude
column11: but your assumptions don\'t hold. Your suggestion works under very limited conditions: OpenSSL on  that have single CA cert PEM file that contains only trust anchors for TLS web server authentication. Some operating systems have a cert directory
column12: Windows and OSX have different sources for trust anchors. Certificates can come from other sources like PKCS#11 providers or a NSS database. You also must ensure that the CA file contains _only_ trust anchors for TLS server auth. Otherwise you will run into big trouble."'

column10: b'b" I\'m not against the idea of using pkg_resource entry point per se. It is that I don\'t like the idea of standardizing an API that is severely limited and broken by design
column11: because requests supports Python versions without a SSLContext object. Let\'s go for a better
column12: more flexible and future proof API. Instead of a where() function that returns a path
column13: the entry point should accept two arguments: a SSLContext object and a purpose flag. Each entry point is then able to install whatever certs
column14: directories or loaders it sees fit."'

b'b\' The snippet provided by @davidfraser doesn\\\'t work how people would expect it to work on Windows. Yes it will enumerate the certificates *currently* in the trust store and add them to the  SSLContext  by default.  However
column11: the word "currently" is very important in that statement. Windows does not ship a full trust store by default
column12: preferring to instead ship a minimal trust store and having SChannel fetch
column13: on demand
column14: additional certificates needed to verify a connection as it needs them. This means that the snippet @davidfraser provided will only verify connections using certificates that have already had their root certificate "seen" by something that uses the system verification APIs via SChannel. The user experience is that on some machines (particularly fresh
column15: new ones) users will find Python failing to validate their TLS connection without any indication that the reason is because they hadn\\\'t triggered SChannel to fetch the correct root certificate prior to running that Python program. \''

b"b' The error is unclear
column11: but most likely it is a result of your OpenSSL version. Your claim that Ubuntu 14.04 has no OpenSSL simply *cannot* be true if you are making HTTPS requests. My best guess is that the server is sending EOF because none of your ciphers are acceptable. Ubuntu works because it has a newer OpenSSL with newer ciphers. Installing PyOpenSSL works because it provides a vendored copy of OpenSSL 1.0.2
column12: also with newer ciphers.'"

column10: b'b" Several times now I\'ve stumbled over cases where I would like to print the request and response objects as strings to the console. Simply to see when headers and content are sent. Seems more people than I have had this problem: url  My suggestion: add two util methods that print requests and responses according to the HTTP spec. They are fully optional to use
column11: and would not break backwards compatibility: To be clear
column12: I\'m suggesting something link this be added to : Is this a good idea?"'

column10: b'b" @EmilStenstrom Generally this is a good idea
column11: but we tend to oppose having \'utility\' functions be merged into requests itself: we want to restrict the scope of the main library so that it remains really good at doing its specific roles. For that reason
column12: you should check out the [requests toolbelt]url  which has exactly the utilities you want."'

column10: b'b" Didn\'t we just have another issue about this a couple days ago?"'

b'b" I actually wouldn\'t be against having something like this added directly to the and classes. I think that functionality is useful enough to warrant inclusion.  Would have to think hard about the name
column11: though."'

column10: b'b"   (defaults to True). I would want it to be a near exact representation of what we\'re going to send across the wire (minus any post processing that occurs in a transport adapter
column11: of course)."'

column10: b'b\' @kennethreitz How "near exact" is "near exact"? Note
column11: for example
column12: that the does not have a header: this is because httplib attaches it for us. It is also missing some headers that urllib3 adds for us. The reality is that Requests does not have access to enough information to render this out unless we want to guess at what the rest of the stack will do
column13: and if we do that then we\\\'ll start getting bugs raised when the output of does not match the actual transmitted bytes.\''

column10: b'b" That may be okay
column11: as we\'d be rendering a representation of the object
column12: not the request itself. It would have to be documented as such. Part of me thinks this is a great idea
column13: the other part has hesitation. It would be nice to be able to to get a quick view of what was sent
column14: rather than having to print a bunch of attrs. "'

column10: b'b" @kennethreitz I have no objection to rendering a representation of the preparedrequest object
column11: but I suspect it\'s _extremely_ unwise to render in a structure that suggests completeness. In particular
column12: the structure given here (which renders out to a \'valid\'  ) doesn\'t work in the following cases:1. If using HTTP/2
column13: when the  are structured entirely differently and made of binary frames.2. If we send a file or send using chunked transfer-encoding
column14: where we cannot render the body before we send it.3. If we _receive_ data using chunked transfer-encoding
column15: where we cannot accurately represent it because urllib3 has transparently removed the chunking.4. If the request is sent via a proxy there\'s an extra CONNECT request we\'re simply not printing. There\'s nothing wrong with wanting to have a printable representation of all the data on the
column16: but we should be very wary before we format that like a  request."'

column10: b'b" Agreed. I think we could make it _look like_ an
column11: but clearly not be one. That would present the data in a friendly and familiar format
column12: but would make it clear this is not a representation of the wire layer. For example
column13: instead of opening with
column14: we\'d open with  ."'

column10: b'b" I\'m open to that direction."'

column11: it caused all of our json requests to fail due to a decoding problem. I\'m unclear why requests even defaults to simple-json anymore. I\'d be happy to contribute to a PR to make the json library for requests more controllable but wanted to submit an issue first. Or perhaps there is another way I\'m unaware of that would allow more control over which json library requests will use."'

column11: I was under the impression that a freshly-compiled has better performance characteristics than the module that is built into Python 2.6. '"

column10: b'b" Controlling imports is _extremely_ fraught because it relies on delaying the import until some later time in the execution. I am pretty averse to doing that because it causes bugs to appear at weird places and can generally make life weirdly tricky. If we\'re going to keep it we should keep it
column11: if we\'re going to remove it we should remove it."'

b'b" Yes I\'ll give my real world scenario ... One library is using requests and after some digging found that it was overriding json decode for various reasons. It works great with requests when using the standard python json library but another python library decided to import simplejson and broke decoding in requests. You could say that to real issue was the override but I think the lack of control over which json library requests use is an issue."'
b"b' It should also be noted that our json support is very simple
column11: and in no way necessary for using the library \\xe2\\x80\\x94 you can easily (although we do a little bit more with encodings
column12: I believe). '"

column11: I doubt it. I specifically said Python 2.6.'"

column10: b'b" Or  . Yes it\'s nice to use a convenience method
column11: but requests has lots of convenience methods that people bypass in certain cases and this is a great example of one case (where you have another requirement on simplejson which should work exactly identically to the standard library\'s json module). Questions about simplejson\'s performance are not relevant to requests though."'

b"b' Consider making Timeout option required or have a default'"
b'b" I have a feeling I\'m about to get a swift education on this topic
column11: but I\'ve been thinking about the  of changing so that somehow there is a timeout value configured for every request. I think there are two ways to do this:1. Provide a default value. I know browsers have a default
column12: so that may be a simple place to begin.2. Make every user configure this in every request -bigger API breakage. Probably not the way to go. The reason I\'m thinking about this is because I\'ve used requests for a few years now and until now I didn\'t realize the importance of providing a timeout. It took one of my programs hanging forever for me to realize that the default here isn\'t really very good for my purposes. (I\'m in the process of updating all my code...) I also see that a lot of people want objects to have a timeout parameter
column13: and this might be a way to do that as well.  If a large default were provided to all requests and all sessions
column14: what negative impact would that have? The only thing I can think of is that some programs will get timeout exceptions where they previously hung
column15: which seems like an improvement to me.## Caveat
column16: added May 13
column17: 2016: Please don\'t use this issue to discuss adding a timeout attribute to requests. There are a number of discussions about this elsewhere (search closed issues)
column18: and we don\'t want that conversation to muddy this issue too. Thanks."'

column10: b'b" This is an entirely reasonable suggestion. Honestly
column11: I\'m not averse to doing it: there are definitely worse things to do than this. I\'d be open to providing a default timeout. However
column12: I don\'t think we can do it until 3.0.0. Of course @kennethreitz as keeper of the spirit of requests has got the final say on this
column13: and should definitely weigh in."'

column10: b'b" Changing the default would definitely need to wait until 3.0.0. I\'m not against having a well-reasoned (and therefore
column11: also well-documented) default timeout parameter. I\'m still pretty strongly against sessions having a timeout attribute though and I think that shouldn\'t muddy the waters of this discussion because it will sidetrack things and prevent an otherwise productive discussion."'
