column11: as designed. The introductory examples are all clearly typed into the Python interactive interpreter
column12: so they have a timeout: the user sitting there can hit ^C anytime they like. I\\\'d welcome enhancements to the "timeouts" section of the documentation to be more emphatic
column13: that certainly does seem reasonable. But I don\\\'t think we need to go through and add the arg. \''

column10: b'b" I think the point that\'s generally acknowledged by this bug is that the design _was_ wrong. There\'s a general consensus here that adding a default timeout or requiring it as an argument is a good idea. The  docs could address that
column11: and that seems like a simple step to take until this issue is resolved in the next major version. What happens in practice is that people grab the examples from the docs
column12: don\'t read the timeout section carefully (or don\'t understand its implications -I didn\'t for years until I got bit)
column13: and then wind up with programs that can hang forever. I completely agree with @chris-martin that until this issue is fixed
column14: all examples in the docs should provide the timeout argument. Otherwise
column15: we\'re providing examples that can (and probably will) break your programs."'

column10: b'b\' There is a substantial difference between "is a good idea in production code" and "should be used in every example". For example
column11: all production code should use Sessions for everything
column12: but the documentation doesn\\\'t do that because it doesn\\\'t help teach the specific lessons that the documentation is intended to teach. While I appreciate the concern that users will blindly copy code out of the documentation without further consideration
column13: anyone doing that in their product is necessarily going to have sub-par results. This is true in all programming tools. \''

column10: b'b" I think that we\'ve addressed this through documentation. I don\'t think any of the core team is going to change the API to require a timeout and I think we\'ve done our diligence here."'

column11: but I *vehemently* disagree with closing this bug without a fix. We improved the documentation via the PR that I filed
column12: but in practice I regularly run into programs that hang because they do not have a timeout. It\'s gotten bad enough that it\'s one of the first things I think of when a program hangs. Requests is a wonderful library but you can\'t document your way out of a problem like this. Look at the list of issues referencing this one. Documentation is just not enough
column13: or else issues would stop referencing this one.  I respect the requests maintainers greatly

column15: that\'s what version bumps are for. But I\'m not even sure API changes would be needed.  Please reconsider."'

column10: b'b\' Has there been any progress on this?  @mlissner To add to your statement
column11: I think that the current situation kind-of contradicts the stated project goal "HTTP Requests for Humans".  Humans need sensible defaults. Not just in graphical user interfaces
column12: but also in command-line user interfaces and software libraries. And "no timeout" is almost never a sensible default. I was very surprised to read about that trap in the manual. This note should be more prominent in the manual
column13: perhaps being the first note in the Quickstart (rather than the last note)
column14: because this is surprising and not what you expect from a library that performs network calls.  (Even better than a more prominent place in the manual
column15: of course
column16: would be to fix this once and for all.)  @sigmavirus24 @chris-martin I fully agree
column17: and I don\\\'t need timeout environment variables
column18: either. All I need is either a sane default timeout
column19: or making the timeout argument mandatory. No more
column20: no less.\''

column10: b'b\' Yup
column11: so the server is wrong.  This is a really common problem with TLS. A TLS certificate validation is performed by first building a *certificate chain* that takes us from a certificate the server can prove it has the private key for (the "leaf") to a certificate we trust (the "root"). For OpenSSL there is an additional rule: the root must be self-signed.  In most cases
column12: this chain is more than two steps long: that is
column13: the leaf is not signed by the root
column14: but is instead signed by a so-called *intermediate* certificate. That intermediate may itself be signed by the root
column15: but may also be signed by *other* intermediates
column16: until we eventually reach an intermediate that was signed by a root.  For example
column17: for url  the chain is as follows:  1. python-
column18: the "leaf"
column19: which I applied for and had issued 2. Let\\\'s Encrypt Authority X3
column20: an intermediate certificate used by the Let\\\'s Encrypt project 3. DST Root CA X3
column21: the root certificate that my web browser (and Requests) trusts  The correct chain for the site you\\\'re accessing *should be*:  1. -
column22: the leaf 2. Entrust Certification Authority L1K
column23: the intermediate certificate which issued the leaf 3. Entrust Root Certification Authority G2
column24: the root certificate that issued the intermediate  For your use case
column25: Requests ships with certificate number 3 in its trust database as a trusted root. However
column26: your server is only sending certificate number 1. Requests cannot go from certificate 1 to certificate 3 without having certificate 2
column27: and the server isn\\\'t sending it. Most browsers ship with commonly-used intermediate certs
column28: or can maintain caches of them
column30: so it has no way of getting hold of certificate 2. Without certificate 2
column31: validation must fail.  Properly-configured TLS servers send the leaf certificate *and all of the necessary intermediaries*. This is to ensure that clients that have never seen the intermediaries and that cannot dynamically fetch them are still able to validate the chain. As a comparison
column32: check out the output of a command like yours run against  :   Note that the server sent *two* certificates in my case
column33: whereas in yours it only sent one.  This is the error. Please reconfigure your server to send all the relevant intermediaries as well as the leaf.  While I\\\'m here
column34: I should note that running Qualys SSL Labs against your server would also have told you about this problem. =)\''

column10: b'b" Thanks @Lukasa for this educational reply you gave! Really appreciate and sorry for troubling with this
column11: it was my TLS-knowledge-gap =) Mostly I went to issues because in was all good in browsers and didn\'t work in requests. But now its clear to me what is the root cause.  I believe there is no workaround (download intermediate cert upfront) for this case
column12: but to reconfigure the server? For the time being I will skip verification checks"'

column10: b'b" @hellt No need to apologise: this is a thing that is extremely non-obvious and it\'s a *really* common error to make
column11: so you\'re in good company here. =)  There is a workaround
column12: in fact. You can pass a certificate bundle to to override the use of certifi\'s bundle. This bundle can
column13: in addition to root certs
column14: contain intermediary certificates that become available to OpenSSL to use to build the chain. As a result
column15: what you can do is take the certifi cert chain (which is in a file you can find by running
column16: copy that out to somewhere else on your filesystem
column17: and then add the intermediate certificate to the end of that file. The intermediate has to be in PEM format. If then pass the path to the new cert bundle to the kwarg
column18: you\'ll find everything starts working."'

b'b" So this is arguably an increase in strictness thanks to our new idna library
column11: but underscores are _not_ allowed in hostnames. See #17 for more. While this previously worked
column12: I suspect that really it shouldn\'t have. Underscores are perfectly allowed in _DNS_
column13: which is why this never encountered a problem prior to this
column14: but for hostnames they\'re entirely forbidden. I\'m inclined to say that this is within the bounds of things that are allowed to stop working in a minor release
column15: as it\'s simply outside the realm of what RFCs allow."'

column10: b'b" To be clear

column15: the argument is a bad one. is defined with a very general ABNF because
column16: as the RFC states
column17: it is not limited to DNS or any specific form of lookups. The host portion of a *general* URI may cover quite a lot of name formats.  However
column18: we aren\\\'t dealing with *general* URIs. We only support URIs that contain either IP address literals (in which case we do no name resolution) or hostnames (in which case we do an A lookup). These are not expected to be generalised names.  However
column19: we need to follow the furrow that browsers have ploughed for us
column20: and they have no interest in enforcing restrictions on URL formatting. This is why we\\\'re working on a fix. **To all other readers of this issue: please do not add your 2\\xc2\\xa2 or "me too"s. We already acknowledge this to be an issue. We are working on a fix. It\\\'s definitely related to the transfer-encoding because chaining a similar set of responses ((http)302->(https)302->(separate server)200) from httpbin won\\\'t trigger the failure. This "bug" was introduced in Requests 2.7.0 (urllib3 1.10.4) but masked by two separate blocks. The first was removed in 2.8.0 in c6c8d64 but this didn\\\'t expose the issue because the exception block was still catching it. 327512f removed the second safeguard which is why 2.12.x is now showing this. I backported 327512f and was able to confirm this only started happening after the chunk transfer work in urllib3 1.10.4. Something causes the underlying socket closed before we can read it for the redirect

column10: b"b' I understand that streaming from the intermediate redirects is a little exotic.  For the record I want to note that the server behaviour is not especially exotic.  With tweaked sample to pass the url ...   '"
b"b' Extra info about the previous run:  '"
b"b' And the downgrade does not generate the traceback:  '"

b'b\' There\\\'s nothing unexpected about streaming the intermediate response. We\\\'re fine with you doing that. What\\\'s wrong is the form of that intermediate response. Allow me to reproduce it for you here (using the original example):   (I have had to hex encode the body to print it out
column11: because it\\\'s not valid ASCII)  Note that this response says
column12: and then provides a non-chunk-encoded body. That body does not obey chunked transfer encoding. This is *an error condition*. The traceback is not wrong. There is no way to safely read this body. That means your attempt to redirect that body into a file *must* fail.  I cannot stress this enough: there is no way Requests can "tolerate" this if you ask us for the body because we cannot read the body. It is an invalid  response
column13: and we cannot tell when the body is supposed to end. The problem here is not the traceback. If anything
column14: the fact that it "works" in the older case is the *actual* bug
column15: because we are pretending to the user that everything is fine when in fact it is very much not fine.  If you are going to handle redirects yourself
column16: then you must be prepared to do what Requests does when it receives a bad body on a redirect response
column17: which is swallow them. It is not our job to swallow them for you when you indicated you want the actual response. We are giving you the response: it is the server\\\'s fault that the response is invalid. Please take it up with them.\''

column10: b"b' I should note that I would be prepared to accept a PR on urllib3 to provide a better exception in this case
column11: because really we should be emitting a urllib3-specific exception here.'"

column10: b"b' Hrm. Further investigation suggests that the chunked transfer encoding here is actually fine. I managed to pull out some specific chunked encoding from curl that works just fine

column10: b'b" Ack
column11: I suspect I know why. We\'re consuming the content twice. If you eat the data via
column12: goes to consume it again and gets all wibbly and confused because it doesn\'t know that you already did. This can be seen by modifying the originally posted code to (note the additional line at the bottom): "'

column10: b'b" So
column11: flags this by setting when it has finished iterating.  I suspect the real culprit here is urllib3\'s custom chunking code
column12: which does not check whether it believes the response is complete or not (in this case
column13: it is
column14: and so it should be short-circuit returning). I think that\'s a bug on urllib3."'

column10: b"b' See #1088. In the meantime
column11: I recommend a workaround when using when iterating redirects that you set to if you have
column12: in fact
column13: consumed the content. Closing in favour of the urllib3 bug.'"

column14: \\\'Content-Encoding\\\': \\\'gzip\\\'
column15: \\\'Content-Type\\\': \\\'*/*\\\'}  however the payload is uncompressed plain-text:   <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3 XHTML 1.0 "   "url "    403 Forbidden    403 Forbidden   This raises a  in  . b'b" Here\'s an example cert that is failing for me: url  (and you can see why in the report) "'
b'b" @myusuf3 @punkrokk Hey folks
column11: it would have been better if the two of you had filed a new issue for this. However
column12: yes
column13: this is a 1024-bit root problem. In this case the fix is to change your requests call to  . As to the idea of disabling cert validation
column14: this is already possible by passing
column15: as a quick look at the docs would have told you. Requests will honor a cert bundle you build if you pass a path to the parameter. If this isn\'t working for you
column16: please file a bug rather than suffer in silence. "'

column10: b'b\' Ok now that I\\\'m at a computer let me answer you more directly and thoroughly.@punkrokk Requests by default *already* trusts the 1024-bit roots (this isn\\\'t a SHA1 concern
column11: it\\\'s a 1024-bit concern). However
column12: when it finds certifi in the environment it automatically updates to use the strong trust bundle present in certifi
column13: which does not trust those roots.That\\\'s nonsensical. If the certificate verification fails
column14: one possibility is that you are under *active man-in-the-middle attack*. Soft-failure of certificate validation is unacceptable: it\\\'s just not an option.Requests does not police the signature algorithms used in a certificate chain.This is because the Google certificate has two possible certificate chains it could build. One leads to a root certificate present in the bundle that has a 2048-bit RSA key. The other leads to a root certificate *not* present in the bundle that has a 1024-bit RSA key. These 1024-bit RSA keys are *desperately* unsafe
column15: and so by default when Requests can find it will not choose to trust them. You can avoid this problem either by moving to a newer OpenSSL or by pointing Requests at  . In the first case
column16: this resolves OpenSSL\\\'s cert chain building problem to allow it to find the 2048-bit root that is actually present. In the second case
column17: this will point to a version of that contains the old
column18: weak roots. I *strongly* recommend doing the first
column19: rather than the second.This validates just fine for me. Your issue isn\\\'t that there is a SHA-1 signature
column20: though that is bad
column21: but because like Google this site uses a cross-signed root certificate. As an explainer of what this is
column22: it occurred because Thawte had issued certificates for a long time that chained up to their [Thawte Premium Server CA]url  root certificate. This root certificate has a 1024-bit RSA key
column23: which is extremely vulnerable to brute-force attacks to recover the private key. If the private key is recovered
column24: it will be possible to create new certificates that appear to have been issued by the Thawte Premium Server CA. For this reason browsers have removed all 1024-bit RSA root certificates from their trust stores and CAs minted new 2048-bit-or-larger roots. However
column25: some older browsers may not have the ability to update their cert stores
column26: and so may not know about the new 2048-bit roots. For this reason
column28: they created two versions of the certificate: one is self-signed
column29: and distributed to trust stores; the other is signed by the old 1024-bit root. This is true of the root CA here
column30: which is [thawte Primary Root CA]url  If you look back in your ssllabs log you\\\'ll see the remote server is sending a copy of this certificate over that is signed by Thawte Premium Server CA. However
column31: if you expand the "certification paths" section of the report you\\\'ll see that the thawte Primary Root CA is being treated as a root
column32: despite not being self-signed. What gives? Well
column33: SSLLabs has a cert chain builder that looks for roots in its trust store *before* it chains up to a cert sent by the remote server. This means that when it looks for a cert called "thawte Primary Root CA" it looks in its trust database (e.g. like  ) for that root cert
column35: it has built a trusted chain. Older OpenSSLs do not do this. They always build a cert chain *first* using the certs sent by the remote server. For this reason
column36: OpenSSL will use the cross-signed root sent by the server
column37: and so will look for Thawte Premium Server CA to root the chain. doesn\\\'t have this cert (because it\\\'s vulnerable to attack)
column38: so OpenSSL gives up. Newer versions of OpenSSL are smarter about this
column39: and so they have no trouble validating a cert chain like this (which is why I don\\\'t encounter the problem). Your advice is the same as what I give to @myusuf3: either upgrade OpenSSL
column40: or use the weak cert bundle. I *strongly* recommend the former.\''

column10: b'b\' By the way
column11: you\\\'ll see that contains [thawte Primary Root CA]url  It also has [Thawte Premium Server CA]url  in a file labelled "old_"
column12: which is where the 1024-bit roots are stored in case they\\\'re needed.\''

column10: b'b"  Requests very deliberately provides no such global switch: turning off certificate validation for all programs that use Requests very easily is a bad idea
column11: and opens up real problems with securing a system. We provide environment variables that allow you to point us at custom cert bundles
column12: which is the recommended solution: point us at your centralised CAs and we\'ll do the right thing."'

b"b' Enable sessions to bypass  cookies.'"
b'b" We use requests for some service-to-service communication
column11: neither side of which utilizes cookies.  When we profiled our services
column12: we see ~13% of the time spend sending requests is either creating cookie jars or extracting cookies to jars.  This PR will enable us to disable cookies for a given by setting  .  If is None
column13: we won\'t create any cookies for the request nor will we parse them on the response."'

column10: b"b' # [Codecov]url  Report[![Impacted file tree graph]url  | [Impacted Files]url  | Coverage \\xce\\x94  []url []url []url []url -[Continue to review full report at Codecov]url '"
b'b\' Thanks for this suggestion!  So
column11: before I go any further
column12: I\\\'d like to get an understanding of your results. You say that 13% of the time is spent "either creating cookie jars or extracting cookies to jars"
column13: but also that your services never use cookies. I find that somewhat tricky to believe: in the event that there are no cookies there will be relatively little processing of the absent cookies.  Firstly
column14: the most expensive things we do in general are related to environment evaluation: checking for proxies
column15: reading files
column16: etc. So I assume you\\\'re already setting to to avoid that overhead.  Secondly
column17: as an attempt to reproduce your results
column18: I profiled Requests making 1000 requests through a single Session to a Twisted instance serving a directory on my machine
column19: with  . This sets no cookies. The total runtime of the test was 4 seconds. Here\\\'s the profiling output
column20: sorted by cumulative time
column21: for any function that we spend more than 100ms in:   As you can see
column22: cookies *are* in there
column23: but only in one place ( )
column24: with a total runtime of 129ms. Now
column26: I suspect the content we\\\'re sending back and forth is longer in my case than in yours
column27: so we can assume that you\\\'d spend less time in
column28: but even if we assumed you spent *zero* time there we don\\\'t get anywhere near to cookies being 30% of the overhead. In the case of my test
column29: the other cookie-based code that is not part of adds maybe another 80ms of overhead
column31: let\\\'s double that estimate to 420ms. 420ms spread across 1000 requests is 420\\xce\\xbcs: not an entirely unreasonable overhead
column32: given that we spend about 1/4 of that time checking that that the connection is still down.  So
column33: certainly if we were going to add this feature I\\\'d want the code to be *vastly* simpler. I\\\'d also want to ask whether or not it\\\'s easier in your case simply to patch the function to be a no-op.\''

column10: b'b" @Lukasa Thanks a ton for your detailed analysis!  I really appreciate all of the work you put into evaluating this \\xf0\\x9f\\x98\\x84 .  Here\'s a snippit of flame graph (Generated using url  from one of our services running in production
column11: filtering out to only focus on  : [only_]url Here\'s a screenshot
column12: highlighting all stacks that contain the word  : (If you\'re not comfortable opening random zips
column13: here\'s the raw output  url
column14: run it through url  to get an SVG)  Thanks for the tip
column15: I noticed how expensive and merging environment settings were but haven\'t had a chance to change things in production.  Any pointers on how we can make the code simpler?  This is my first requests PR so I\'m not super familiar with the coding style here beyond what\'s in the docs."'

column10: b"b' Making it simpler would focus on moving the complexity into helper functions that deal with this. For example
column11: could be enhanced to handle arguments
column12: keeping this complexity out of the main code paths.'"

column10: b'b" Thanks for the suggestion @Lukasa
column11: I\'ve simplified the implementation to encapsulate some of the complexity inside of  .  One other thing I wanted to run by you: setting to to avoid  cookies feels somewhat magic to me.  Do you think it would be better if there were simply a flag?  The main motivator for structuring like this is the behavior I\'d expect if the has no cookies but the does is we would pass through the requests cookies and having set to while specifying cookies would be illegal (I tend to be a big fan of the idea that illegal states should be unrepresentable when possible)."'

column10: b'b" @Lukasa one additional thought I just had reading your comment I\'m most worried about optimizing CPU consumption
column11: not wall time.  Totally agree that this will have minimal impact on wall time
column12: but for some services that simply farm out a bunch of requests and wait for their response (using gevent) the CPU consumed here is non-trivial.  For servers using threads
column13: I worry that the RLock on the cookiejar is creating contention so it\'d be best if we could avoid it all together."'

column10: b'b"  No. =) We strongly
column11: strongly resist adding API surface because it adds to the possible confusion of interacting with Requests. This goes double for situations like yours which are extremely uncommon: adding an entire additional API property for a bit of function that fewer than 0.5% of users will ever use is just complete overkill. I\'d much rather add a subtle use of an existing property. What makes this state illegal? Setting requests that no cookies be *persisted*
column12: but there\'s no reason to prevent you putting cookie headers in the request. In fact
column13: this is a good example as to why we don\'t want to add such a flag: it is unclear what exactly it applies to
column14: and there are numerous other flags and options that it *could* apply to
column15: so I\'d say it impedes clarity more than anything else. It probably is
column16: but not by much. After all
column17: we have a lock in the connection pool too
column18: though admittedly it\'s one in the default configuration that you can\'t contend on (more a semaphore than a lock in that case). Merely *having* the lock
column19: even if you don\'t contend on it
column20: is very expensive in Python.  I agree that minimising CPU time is important
column21: but if you want to do that I *strongly* encourage you to look away from Requests. Requests\' attempts to provide you with a helpful
column22: intuitive API involve a *lot* of Python code that is strictly overhead. If you can ensure that your HTTP data will always be ready to go and require basically zero transformation you may find urllib3 is a better fit for your needs."'

column14: that opens up an enormous chunk of the ecosystem to being able to use these newer Python packaging tools. Python packaging is such a commonly complained about topic

column16: which means no longer distributing wheels

column19: Windows users often have *up-to-date* pips)

b'b\' I\\\'m so grateful you decided to fix this as it broke at least two of our Ubuntu based stacks in QA and in Integration.  Thank god we deployed production early this morning!  People read instructions to install things like New Relic or Rollbar which use pip.  It really isn\\\'t the end users fault that Ubuntu 16.04 LTS is using an older version of pip and breaks.  I doubt many people installing tools like New Relic have a clue what "requests" is.  Ubuntu 14.04 pip 1.5.4 Ubuntu 16.04 pip 8.1.1 (That\\\'s why those two versions are 2.1 million downloads in the past 30 days)  People lock in versions thinking the release isn\\\'t going to change.  When it goes and grabs updating packages it can come as quite a surprise.  Over the 4 hours this was broken it took two engineers about 3 hours to identify the problem and start fixing servers.  Another 30 QA+Dev engineers were unable to deploy and test changes.  I can\\\'t imagine how many people were impacted as a whole.  Short term I\\\'ll be up tonight adding upgrading pip to the latest version in all of our pipelines.  Long term I will try to make sure we always use our package manager and never use pip to install anything on a server.\''
b'b" Thanks to @Lukasa for handling this so well.  It\'s not always easy to deal with the users
column11: especially when they\'re all on your GitHub issue at once
column12: but it\'s clear the folks care \\xf0\\x9f\\x98\\x84 ."'

column10: b"b' Well done on finding a mitigation that improves compatibility with earlier pip versions.  Longer term
column11: it likely makes sense to use this case as an example for why wrapping a virtual environment in an immutable deployment artifact (e.g. container
column12: deb
column13: RPM) or locking all your transitive Python level dependencies (e.g. with pip-tools or ) is a good idea even the most diligent of developers can accidentally introduce incompatibilities with older distros
column14: and tools like pipenv and  help ensure your worst case scenario in such instances is a failure in pre-merge CI for a dependency update rather than a broken deployment pipeline or production environment.'"

column10: b'b" @tgamblin Thanks to all of you! We\'ve had stuff like this in the past
column11: and it\'s really easy for a GitHub thread like this one to get heated and out of control. It\'s always good to have a community work together
column12: both maintainers and users
column13: to try to find some kind of reasonable outcome that helps everybody. So far I think we\'ve done that
column14: though we\'ll keep a careful eye on bug reports for the next few weeks and months to see whether we\'ve got an ongoing long-tail of users who are encountering trouble.  @ncoghlan Yeah
column15: there are still some wider Python community things we can look to do to try to reduce the pain of these updates. The pip maintainers have made it clear to me that in general pip is upgraded very frequently: after a release it takes less than 24 hours for the plurality of downloads to be coming from the newest pip release. Looking at our download graphs
column16: the older pips with large download counts can almost always be traced back to the system pip shipped with Linux distributions.  This suggests that there are users that have landed on a developer workflow that involves using the system Python toolchain without appropriate bounding on versions. As has been pointed out by upthread by @martin-langhoff this is in many cases happening transitively
column17: where the top-level dependency is pinned but it has an unpinned dependency in its dependency tree
column18: but it nonetheless leads to a place where users are hoping to build a stable environment and not getting one. It\'s one thing when the breakage happens due to projects being insufficiently careful with their versioning
column19: it\'s quite another when a project becomes incompatible with the *toolchain* you\'re using!  Hopefully we\'ll find a way to help developers in situations like these use better tooling to ensure that the stable environment they want to have is the one that they actually do have.   And with that
column20: I\'m going to close this thread. I had a whole night\'s sleep without anything going particularly wrong with our mitigation
column21: which suggests it\'s working pretty well for now. Of course
column22: if people run into trouble with it you should feel free to comment here and we\'ll work with you to try to resolve it. Thanks for all your time everyone! :heart: :cake: :sparkles:"'

column10: b'b" I observed something odd:   Seems to work in a session the second time around! Tempting to say this is actually about cookies. The first request is without cookies and the webserver 404s because of that whilst still setting some session cookies. The next request sends the cookies and the webserver 200s.  **BUT**
column11: notice that the second request now does not need a redirect; you could replace the second request with and still get a 200
column12: not a 302. Hence the only reason it works now is that redirection is being sidestepped with cookies. This indicates the encoding issues are taking place somewhere in the redirect chain.  **There is one weird thing too:**  In [11]: (u\'url \\xc3\\x83\\xc2\\xa8r-cru-brocard-75cl\')   Out[11]: despite no . I am struggling to understand that. The location header of the redirect in this case looks like:   \'Location\':  \'url i.e. we have the utf8 encoded u\'\\xc3\\xa8\' instead of latin1 encoded.  Our in this case was:  \'url from which the original unicode url can be recovered with  In [46]: print ().decode(\'utf8\').encode(\'latin1\').decode(\'utf8\')   url \\xc3\\xa8r-cru-brocard-75cl  So webserver is using latin1 it seems....  "'

column10: b'b\'  What\\\'s the difference between a "source archive" and a "source distribution"? I\\\'m missing your point.  My goal is to be able to run the tests as part of the Gentoo Linux build script for this package. We skip this currently; otherwise I would have noticed the missing files sooner.\''

b'b"  One (a source archive) is literally the archive of the repository made by setuptools and uploaded to PyPI. The other (a source distribution) is meant to actually be installed by things Python tooling for an end user. One is meant as historical data
column11: the other as an actual installable product (for lack of a better term). One can be downloaded by downstream redistributors and used to run tests
column12: the other is meant to be downloaded and used by users. And that\'s an admirable goal. No one wants a downstream redistributor to package something incorrectly and only find out about it from users."'

b"b' Custom Auth Handler HTTP Method and Body changes not functioning with re-direct'"
b'b\' Hello
column11: I\\\'ve written a pretty basic Custom Authentication Handler to work with a vendor product we have deployed.  This product requires an HTTP request with a  to a specific web-endpoint which will generate an \\\'authentication token\\\' that expires at a set time.  This authentication token is then passed with future requests which will authorize access to the services.  I successfully have this working by setting the PreparedRequest "method" to POST and update the body to include the authorization token.  I have been successful with this if I access a URL that does not have a re-direct.  Unfortunately I\\\'ve stumbled across a few re-directs in the system
column12: and it seems that my method overwrite (from get I enabled IIS Failed Request Tracing on the server side to confirm this scenario.  I can see the following requests: **1st Request** Generate the authentication token with .  Successful HTTP 200 response with the token returned.  My Custom Auth Handler uses this token to update the **2nd Request** Executed HTTP POST to the protected management console (that requires this token).  Server responds with an HTTP Status code 302 (re-direct) with a new location in the response header (in this case it just added a \\\'/\\\' at the end of the path).  I can see my authorization token in the request body  **3rd Request** Requests does follow the re-direct
column13: however it is re-converted back to an HTTP GET and my token (from the body) is also lost.  It does appear that my request headers did persist.  Thoughts?  Thanks for any help!!!\''

column10: b'b" Have you considered having the auth handler be stored on the Session object
column11: and also have it do its own request creation to obtain auth tokens? Essentially
column12: if it has an auth token it will just add it to all requests
column13: and if it doesn\'t it will obtain one by making its own brand new request instead of by mutating the one the user is making?"'

column10: b"b' Thanks for the feedback!  I will take a look at that.  Currently every request will generate another token passing the  every time (increasing the overall chatter).  The session enhancement should fix that issue as well.  Since this posting... the code base was uploaded to: url '"
b'b" So
column11: I\'ve spent some time playing with requests Sessions and can confirm that my authentication handler works with that approach
column12: however
column13: I think there is still an issue to be discussed.  Here is the current control flow: Developer creates an auth instance providing a .  The auth instance is added to a request (or a session).  On the **first request**... the auth instance will execute its own request to the server \'get token\' endpoint
column14: provide the  and obtain the authorization token.  The auth instance will store the token and the  it expires (default is 60 min).  On all requests (first and subsequent)
column15: the auth instance will:  Check token \'expires\' timestamp and acquire a new one if needed   Change the  to POST   Add the token parameter to the PreparedRequest body  I can confirm that if I am accessing a URL that does not have a re-direct (HTTP 302)
column16: that everything works as expected.  The request is modified to a POST and the token is present in the body.  If
column17: however
column18: there is an HTTP re-direct (302) then the requests API will follow the new **location** (defined in the response header)
column19: but the method gets set back to GET (if it was truly a GET originally)
column20: and the token is dropped from the body.  So I\'m guessing there is an issue with re-directs not persisting the method and body changes of the request.  So a couple questions...  **Should it be a legitimate implementation approach to:**  1. **allow an auth handler to adjust the request body?** I looked through a couple of other auth handlers (like the HTTP Basic
column21: NTLM and Kerberos handlers) and it appears those just modify request headers (www-authenticate).  I think yes.  If so
column22: should this be classified as a bug?  2. **allow an auth handler to force the request method (for this example POST)?**  I could see this getting a little hairy
column23: however HTTP POST requests are supposed to be more secure than HTTP GET requests (and in this case the token represents a users identity
column24: hence the need to protect confidentiality of this data payload as best as possible).  I might be able to register a response hook for HTTP 302 (or other re-directs) and possibly handle this scenario
column25: if it is deemed that the underlying requests API will not be adjusted to account for this scenario.  Thanks!   "'

column10: b'b" I\'m not a contributor so feel free to take what I say with a grain of salt
column11: but #3107 looks at the fact that POST gets changed to GET upon a HTTP 302 as that\'s what sending a 302 is telling requests to do
column12: so that much is working as intended. You could always set in the request
column13: capture the Location header yourself and then perform the new request. Or... get the server to return a 307/308 not a 302
column14: as mentioned in #3107 "'

column10: b"b' An auth handler is free to do *whatever it likes*. It can arbitrarily transform a request as it sees fit.  As to the redirect auth-stripping
column11: I think that that is actually a separate bug: should probably re-apply any auth handler that is present
column12: which it currently does not.'"

column10: b'b" Thank you all for the feedback.  I\'ve updated the code base url  to handle re-directs.  I\'m currently having problems with the vendor product recognizing my token in the body and had to revert to placing that in the URL query string (which I would rather not do since I know it is logged all over the server access logs).  This mimics the behavior I see in the vendor products management console (requests to the back-end \'admin\' REST API are all HTTP GET with the token passed in a URL Query-String Parameter).  At any rate
column11: I think this is functioning well enough to start using in some operational tools.  I\'ll leave this issue open for another day or two in case someone wants to collaborate on this scenario
column12: otherwise I\'ll close it. Thanks!! "'

We can\'t get this working with requests. I tried the toolbelt as well as may other adapters I found on the internet. Then pass the logical host through so that the proxy can route the logical server name to the correct backend. column10: b'b" Requests will return uncompressed content by default so it can be written directly to file or passed around your code in the intended base format. Lots of web servers send content

column13: you\'ll receive the tar file.  If this is conda-build\'s code

column10: b'b" This isn\'t how redirects work. The RFCs (3986
column16: 7235) do not require or prescribe retaining the fragment. If you want us to retain the fragment you\'ll need to handle redirects yourself. The server is telling us what to redirect to and we\'re supposed to follow that.  Thanks for opening this issue to clarify."'

column10: b"b' Copy cookie policy when copying a CookieJar'"
b"b' # [Codecov]url  Report[![Impacted file tree graph]url  | [Impacted Files]url  | Coverage \\xce\\x94  []url -[Continue to review full report at Codecov]url '"
b'b" Hey @laurentb
column11: thanks for contributing to Requests! This is something we\'ve looked to support in the past but it\'s had some nuances that have prevented possible solutions being merged.  When we perform a [request]url  (or [redirect]url  a function called will create a new cookie jar and then merge both the session and local cookies together. This loses the policy information because we aren\'t guaranteed both objects being RequestsCookieJars. #3463 was an attempt to solve some of this issue but there was some pushback because session-level cookies are problematic in regards to domain specifications and security.  All that said
column12: if you\'re really just looking to carry over the policy in the method
column13: I think something we could consider. We may want to create a wrapper on RequestsCookieJar though so we\'re not directly calling a CookieLib private variable. We should probably remove the second test too because it suggests this patch fixes something it doesn\'t. If you run the test without the policy change
column14: it will still pass."'

column10: b'b" Thanks
column11: I have indeed a weird issue with redirections and cookies that I\'m trying to fix. It\'s good to see there are issues similar to mine
column12: I found the too but wasn\'t sure what to do with it yet.  In the meantime I\'m at least removing my useless test.  Since I\'m already using a subclass of RequestsCookieJar url  I don\'t really need the fix in copy(). We do a lot of stuff around requests (e.g. url  that may also explain why the fix is enough for me. Yes
column13: that bugged me too :) I\'m adding a last commit to make it public. I suppose that one would be useful to everyone
column14: so I can split it off to a separate pull request if needed."'

b'b\' Are the imports and checks of chardet
column11: pyopenssl & cryptography still needed once Python 2 is dropped?  I ask
column12: as my CLI applications are really sensitive to import time / human perception of how fast the command is
column13: and these modules add a fair amount of import overhead
column14: as found via "python3.7 -Ximporttime"  Thanks\''

column10: b'b"  chardet is required across Py2 and 3.  /  will likely be needed as we continue to support older Python 3 versions that aren\'t as secure as the latest.  As for the
column11: I\'m guessing you mean version checks. In which case
column12: we will not drop those because it\'s our only mechanism for telling users they\'re using unsupported software configurations that mean we will not help them with bugs. Yes
column13: cryptography adds import time and so does chardet. I\'m surprised you haven\'t complained about idna as well since that also adds a lot of overhead just by importing it. There\'s little we can do to reduce that without outright removing features (automatic character encoding detection (chardet)
column14: security ()
column15: internationalized domain name handling (idna)) that are standard for HTTP clients in any language."'

column13: but the version checking & other usage code (such as "def apparent_encoding" assume these modules are there. If you would be open to selective loading or deferred loading
column14: I can create a PR.\''

b"b' Normalize percent-encoded bytes before comparison'"

b'b" urllib3 replaced it\'s URL parser with for more compliant parsing (urllib3/urllib3#1487). We\'ve also got an effort underway to run downstream tests before releases (urllib3/urllib3#1508) and during that process we\'ve discovered that requests requires percent-encoded bytes to keep their casing.  Adding this to the unit tests would allow either version of preand post-rfc3986 urllib3 to pass requests unit tests. I don\'t know if the attribute needs to maintain it\'s casing in this situation or not
column11: if it does this is not the solution. Just putting this together as a potential solution."'

column10: b'b" requests can\'t properly handle redirects if the response body is encoded in something else than \'utf8\'"'

b"b' Just like in the topic. The response body is encoded in iso-8859-2 and the location happens to contain non-ascii character so that it results in UnicodeDecodeError being thrown.  ## Expected Result  Flawless execution of the code.  ## Actual Result  UnicodeDecodeError  ## Reproduction Steps   ## System Information  $ python -m  This command is only available on Requests v2.16.4 and greater. Otherwise
column11: please provide some basic information about your system (Python version
column12: operating system

column10: b"b' Hi @loocash
column11: would you mind providing the stacktrace so we can see where exactly this is failing?'"

column10: b'b" The encoding of the response body is irrelevant here. The location header should be strictly ascii encoded. (See eg. url Requests will (reasonably enough) decode it as utf8
column11: since it is ascii compatible
column12: and ends up being more robust in practice.  In short: The address is serving an invalid HTTP response.   (As an aside it also doesn\'t include \'iso-8859-2\' in the content-type
column13: so there\'s really no way to determine what the intended content type of the byte sequence might be)  Requests *could* decode the header with or something like that
column14: in order to be more robust against malformed headers
column15: but it\'d just be masking the issue that the response header is malformed."'

b"b' So dig into urllib. How does it interpret that byte sequence (where does it redirect to exactly?). Does it just ignore malformed bytes in the location header
column11: or does it do something else?  One resolution here could be to add an errors=... keyword argument to the to_native_string function
column12: and use \\xe2\\x80\\x9cignore\\xe2\\x80\\x9d in the get_redirect_target case. '"

column10: b"b' I\\xe2\\x80\\x99d retitle the issue as \\xe2\\x80\\x9cDeal with malformed Location header gracefully\\xe2\\x80\\x9d.  Erroring is a perfectly legitimate behaviour here
column11: but ignoring the invalid bits of byte sequences *might* (or might not) be preferable. '"
